I am a 40 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 13 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This is basically the developer's previous game What The Dub with a different focus, aesthetic, and some improvements. Considering What The Dub is absolutely fantastic and always a great time with friends, I'll happily pay 10 bucks for more of it.

This feels like a flash game, and that's intended as a compliment. Years ago you could go on Newgrounds or Kongregate and the like and find shooters like this, maybe a little rough and unpolished but clearly designed with passion. It's the graphics and music that most strongly evoke this comparison, but the overall "vibe" of the game reminds me of those days.As for the gameplay itself? Solid. Operation STEEL wears it's inspirations on it's sleeve, with the level set-up taken from Darius and the punishing difficulty of Gradius (the Option's even available!). Some deaths will feel a little cheap until you learn the patterns, but that's kind of par for the course with the games that inspired this.So yeah, pretty good stuff. Operation STEEL won't win any awards for originality, but it does what it sets out to do. If you like old shooters, be they the arcade originals or the indie stuff of the 2000s, give it a look.
Playing this game makes me feel like I'm wasting my life, what with the grind, so can't say I'd recommend it.

Interesting, but ultimately I have to give this a thumbs down. Combat and party mechanics are intriguing, but unlikable characters and "gotcha" moments eventually frustrated me enough to stop playing.I think the point of no return was when the game gives you the ability to smash walls and then walls don't STAY smashed, they magically repair when you leave the labyrinth and return. It's probably engine limitations or the like, but come on, if you're going to give players the ability to break your dungeons, let them have fun with it!

Surprisingly fun. Sometimes a little action game like this is all you need. The entire game is a homage to Castlevania, and considering it's made by one guy it comes off as charming rather than a rip-off. I got a few hours of entertainment out of this and that's worth 3 dollars to me.

This is a mediocre version of a great game.The graphics went with pre-rendered art for the action and overworld scenes and art stills for characters. Some folks think it's ugly, and while I can see that, I think it works. This game clearly wasn't made on a huge budget and it gets the job done.Sound design is definitely a mixed bag. They got the original composer to do another take on his decades-old work, and while the music itself continues to be fantastic, you can tell he was kinda phoning it in. Several tracks take obvious cues from the Actraiser Symphonic Suite album that's as old as the game itself, and music repeats. A lot. Fillmore's Act 1 music is rousing and memorable for the first stage, but it kinda loses it's novelty when it's in *every single Fillmore lair AND act 2*. And what music that's completely new is forgettable.And that brings me to my biggest complaint: the changes to gameplay. All of it just feels so unnecessary. They gave your godly avatar combos and aerial attacks, while also making every single enemy in the game take more hits to defeat. The very first foe encountered is defeated in one hit on the SNES original and takes several hits here. Same goes for the first boss, who is notably more durable. It elongates the fights in a way that I don't think is meaningful. And while they changed the way magic is used so it's a more reliable form of damage, in practice you'll be using it the same way you did in 1990, spamming your best spell to pummel bosses into submission.All of the above is just in the action stages. The changes in the sim mode... Eesh. The angel now has homing arrows, making combat in that mode even more of a non-issue than it was in the original. And the tower defense mode very much overstays it's welcome - it lacks depth while simultaneously being frustrating at times because of the lack of options, not to mention it gets in the way of building the town since you have to sacrifice space for defenses. And it's so frequent! If the horde battles occurred once per town it would be an event and likely more interesting, but as it is you're going to do dozens of battles in sim mode before the game is over and you'll have seen everything they have to offer by the time you reach the second town. I get what they were going for but I don't think they pulled off the execution.Also I think the characters talk too much, even compared to the original where they interrupt you every 5 seconds, but that's just me.If you've never heard of or played Actraiser, by all means, check it out. It's still a very solid game at the end of the day. But for anyone who's played the original, just go play that again instead.

Edit: Since writing this the developer has fixed the issues I mentioned. The game isn't perfect but very solid now. Big thumbs up!In short, a solid game that needs a little more love from the developer.SNKRX delivers on it's concept - a roguelike snake shooter. Combat is punchy with great effects for enemies being knocked backl and allies dying, among other things. Top-notch music too. The graphics are basic but this is a game where that doesn't matter, they relay all the necessary information about your situation at a moment's glance.Customization is great as well. The various classes, their upgrades, and their set abilities make for a lot of fun possibilities.That said, there's a little room for improvement. Even more customization in the form of being able to change your snake's hero layout would be great for the more positional-focused heroes. And as of this writing, the difficulty upgrade from beating the game is permanent unless you go into the game's data and tweak a setting in a text file, which is hardly ideal. There's a few other small gripes here and there as well, some general polish would be in order. I'm hoping for this portion of my review to become obsolete eventually.Overall, if the concept intrigues you at all, buy it. It's great entertainment for a few hours at a low price. The game gets a thumbs up despite the things that bug me, and hopefully the developer will keep polishing until it's a real gem.

I got this game yesterday and lost 4 hours in the blink of an eye playing it. Regardless of anything else, that's the sign of a good time right there.It's still a little buggy at the time of writing, and online co-op would be nice (but understandable that it isn't in), so it isn't perfect. Still, this gets a thumbs up from me. Seems like one of the better old-fashioned shooters on Steam.

Do you enjoy breaking your legs? Do you dream of being able to do so over and over and over? Is your spine just really not that important to you? Then Salt and Sanctuary is the game for you!Yes, Salt and Sanctuary, the world's premier acrophobia simulator! Travel a mysterious island, face off against dangerous monsters, and shatter your bones amongst a remarkable variety of pits, chasms, deadfalls, plateaus, and incredible heights! See the sights of a vast and unique landscape as your body flies past them to your demise! You can stab a beast but you can't defeat gravity!If this appeals to you, then buy Salt and Sanctuary today! You'll FALL in love with it!(seriously though it's a great game but the drops will kill you far more than any enemy or boss will)

Do you like cliche tropes involving Satan and doing the exact same puzzle and platforming segment over and over and OVER? Then this game is for you!Or, you know, load up any mmo. Somehow those are less boring.Seriously, you do the whole run/jump/shoot segment with the pony dozens of times, with very little variation. And the hacking puzzles remain basically the same throughout - even when a new element is introduced, it's subsequently run into the ground.

Good lord I feel like this is a metaphor for life or something. There's interesting things, there's promising things, there's disappointing things, there's horrible things, things seem so bad and heavy and confusing, and at the end of it all you feel relieved and kind of happy.And the soundtrack is pretty dang good too, and given the music driven battles, it better be.One extremely fair warning: this game can be visually harsh. There's plenty of flashing colors, bright lights and a lot of screen warping. If you're visually sensitive, this may not be the game for you. There's some accessibility options to help, but it doesn't fully solve the issue. Just a heads up.

Quality remaster of one of my old PSX favorites. A very love it or hate it game, and I'm on the side of loving it.The remaster mainly brings forth improved visuals in every aspect except NPC sprites (which I feel is a fine choice) and gorgeous arrangements of the original soundtrack, both major wins in my book. Environments and backgrounds have a lovely watercolor painting-esque look that's very appealing to designs, and the soundtrack was already great, but now even much better.Now on a matter of gameplay, it's a divisive subject. Combat on a whole is pretty good; numerous weapons to choose from that all have their own movesets (though basic combos can be the same for many of them, and some special techniques are shared) and attack timings. This is not the mashing kind of game, as mistimed or rapid inputs will cause you to freeze and place and be open for attacks. It all makes for a rather enjoyable loop, though some may find it boring. If you know how Mana combat typically is, you'll be fine.The divisive part comes with the rest of the game. There's a large emphasis on imagination and creating the sort of world you desire. The world map starts out completely empty and you place artifacts that form areas where you will adventure and quest through. There are three main character storylines and a few smaller storylines to follow through this artifact placement. While the main stories can be achieved through regular casual play, if you want to see all stories and do all content, you're in dire need of a guide for artifact placement; else you're at great risk of locking yourself out of content.The game does not explain this to you, which is a missed opportunity for this remaster.In addition to this, the game has a strong tendency to be cryptic and utterly insane with some stories, characters. This personally doesn't bother me, but can be a turn off for some people.Furthermore, there is a fairly indepth gear crafting system filled with many rules and secrets that the game also doesn't explain (kind of, but you have to dig through the in game books and figure out how it all works) which can be frustrating to the point you'll just google how to make some good gear lol.Though you eventually learn much of this is intentional, as it is designed to be replayed.All in all, I really do enjoy this game, and it cements its place as my 2nd favorite Mana game.
You know what this game is, and it's pretty much 5 games in one at it's current full completion. It's good.

I love it.It's funny cause I overlooked it maybe 2 or 3 times. A friend showed me the Switch trailer sometime back and I went "oh that's neat" then sorta forgot about it. Then after playing it, he sang its praises and was quite sad it was going unnoticed. Then again I forgot about it. Then recently another friend linked a song from it ("Mine", the song in the trailer to be exact), and I checked out another two songs and realized they were from this game and they recommended that I check it out.I figure hey, it does look cool, and it's on sale, and if I don't like it, there's always a refund.I was immediately drawn in.At the core of it, it's a bit of an action rhythm game; it's on rails, you can pretty much move freely to collect hearts which is on rhythm with the song of the stage, which raises a multiplier that all goes toward a score. Sometimes there's bits that require timed inputs, again, to the rhythm. But what's mostly interesting to me is the sheer variety. Even though its on rails, it doesn't get old. Running sequences, bike riding sequences, car driving sequences (complete with drifting), sailing a boat, combat sequences, boss battles; plenty to keep you wondering what comes next.The game's presentation is quite strong, though be warned if you're sensitive to flashing lights; there's lot of bright flickers and flashes to add to the spectacle, and one stage in particular has a persistent rainbow glow that might bother you. Visually you have a sort of vaporwave-y aesthetic that goes quite well with the style of the game, and the music (the core of it all of course) is fantastic.As for how long the game is, that depends on you. If you don't care to collect all the diamond squares littered in stages, or aim for gold rank scores, or do the riddles, you can blow through the game pretty fast. And even doing everything, honestly I'd say it takes less than 10 hours. But it's certainly worth the price I picked it up for during the Winter sale.
If you liked Cat Quest 1, you'll like this. For the most part, it's more of the same, and there's nothing wrong with that. The Gentlebros did a wonderful job of turning DLC into a full game.

At some point, you heard about this series. Maybe you were interested, but found it cumbersome and tedious to play. You probably gave it multiple attempts, and it didn't vibe with you, or you weren't keen on playing a handheld game for hours for a game of this nature.Well look no further. Monster Hunter World is the one for you.I don't like to call myself a vet or anything, but I have been playing the series since Monster Hunter Tri, back on the Wii. I honestly hated it for about 3 hours, until something clicked, and then I fell in love with the series. The thing is though, it was a hard thing to recommend to others, the classic games had some mandatory tedium to get through before you get to the fun stuff, but World does away with all of that. The quality of life changes and more lively environments (if you're into that, I can take it or leave it) make it a far more easy-to-get-into experience.As for the game itself, yes it's a farm and a grind, but the game loop and feedback of combat is what keeps you playing. Kill/capture an enemy, use its parts to make stuff, do it to another monster and so on. On paper it sounds kind of repetitive, but when you're actually doing it, it's a wonderful joy.I wholeheartedly recommend it.
Yes.

No it doesn't have anything to do with Undertale.Visually it's a cute looking game, lots of bright colors and decent designs that's pleasing to the eye. Not too much to say there, nothing overly stunning for me but all the visuals work. One thing to be aware of is that there's many moments of flashing lights; if you're sensitive to that kind of thing, be warned.Sound wise it's nothing special, there's only maybe one track that I can say I particularly liked, but the music isn't bad. SFX wise, I'm a little confused by the enemy death noise from the classic Sonic games being used for when the main character gets surprised, but other than that, it's fine.Now gameplay I have a few words. In a way, it reminds me of Super Paper Mario but if you still wanted to have a battle system instead. This comes right down to some very uninspired platforming. Moving platforms, spikes, falling platforms, blah blah. It's really nothing impressive and movement doesn't feel particularly great, just functional. However, the other gameplay elements aren't half bad. The battle system is slow, but has some fine systems in place. For starters, battles are a bit more free form, not being turn based, but rather timing based. You have a sword attack to hit what's directly in front of you, a slingshot to hit ranged and flying enemies, and a hammer which is VERY slow (and prone to getting interrupted) but does amazing damage, with slightly better range coverage compared to sword due to its attack arc. To prevent you from just spamming attacks, there's a stamina bar, which when depleted will leave you vulnurable; unable to attack or dodge. Similar to the first two Paper Marios or the Mario & Luigi games, you can time jumps (or crouches or even shield parries) to avoid damage and get a rapid refill to your stamina bar, allowing you to attack quickly. You can even do bonus damage if you time your attacks to the beat of the music, something you'd most likely do on accident than anything else.Bosses themselves will be a mix of puzzles, platforming challenges and this battle system.The story is uh...it's alright, it's a bit all over the place and gets a little...questionable during it's final hour. But at the very least I did like the characters and some of the humor, while not great, was enjoyable.Overall, I like the game, but it's a very conflicting kind of like. Not a perfect game by any means, but a decent one at least.

It's Dragon Quest, it's Musou/(Dynasty) Warriors, and it makes for a fine blend of the two while stepping away from the standard Musou style of capturing bases and the like to be more of a hack n slash jRPG. Good game if you know what you're getting into. Mashy, stylish, lots of variety between main character classes, weapons and different characters, and plenty of grind.What this isn't however, is a good port. With my previous rig, the game was virtually unplayable in that not only did it take me a bit to get running, but the graphics would often freak out and stretch all over the place.  It ran better on my current rig, but there are still some functional issues depending if you run it windowed, fullscreen, or borderless. And if that wasn't enough, it would outright not recognize your controller input sometimes, which I learned is easily fixed by alt tabbing out and then back in. And multiplayer works when it feels like it.I like the game itself enough to recommend it but I'm pretty glad to be done with it.

I'm not finished with it yet but I can safely say I LOVE this game. I'm pleased with just about every aspect about it. I love how satisfying and cathartic the combat is; all the heavy hits and Heat actions (those cinematic special moves you may have seen) have a satisfying punch that I enjoy no matter how many times I see them, even if some of them make me wince (that Heat action with the Pliers...oof).The characters are great, the story is interesting, the music is lovely.The only knock I have against it is that while the game is like speeding down a highway, there are moments you might get stuck in traffic. There are bits where things seem to slow down in pace and progress, especially when you need to make money for more expensive ventures, but believe me when I say the payoffs are worth it. Everything is rewarded in satisfying or at least hilarious ways.There's just this nice, over the top flair packed in the game's personality that I can easily recommend it.
Used to be great, but then they made a big oopsie and are doubling down on it, it's truly a shame.RIP VRChat 2017 - 2022

This game is pure art. The gameplay is pretty mediocre, the graphics aren't the best, but the story and characters and setting just oozes so much personality, and it just feels like this game was made because of someone's weird idea(s) that they wanted to put out there for many people to see.I played this back on the Xbox 360 waaay back in 2009 or so, I don't really remember. I just remember totally falling in love with everything so weird and quirky about it. The controls take a bit to get used to, but it's not horrible or unplayable by any means.HOWEVER, I do not recommend this port. It's a terrible port imo, and many other people have agreed. I was only able to get a few hours into the Steam version, just because there are so many issues that I doubt will ever be fixed. Playing it with a controller seems to be hit-or-miss, at least for me. I was able to use my Xbox 360 controller plugged in for a while, but trying again recently has just been total failure. I'm not really a fan of the keyboard controls, but I guess it's better than nothing if nothing else will work. There's also a really annoying issue with when you're driving around, where this obnoxious screeching/breaking car noise just keeps happening over and over and over again. Apparently it has something to do with audio drivers or something, I have no idea. It's just something that I guess there is a fix(?) for, but as far as I know, and as far as my experience is, it does not work all the time. That particular bug/issue doesn't seem to happen when I play through my speakers, but that's just one of the many issues I've seen and/or heard about this port.Once again, this game is a cult classic and definitely worth checking out, but I'd say get the Xbox 360 or the PS3 version if you can. The controls are always gonna be janky and bad, but it just takes a few hours of getting used to and they don't seem to be too much of a problem, at least the way I remember it....What did you think of that, Zach? Was that a good enough review?

For the love of god everyone needs to play this, it's inexpensive and it's yet another AMAZING indie game with such a good story that's just.. I love it.I get a bit excited after finishing games and stuff that have an enriching story and characters and etc, and sometimes afterwards I'll maybe think that I was going a bit overboard and it really wasn't THAT great; and hell this may even be one of those games again after I look back on it in a few months or so.But as of right now, this is one of the games that I've played where I will look back on it and think fondly, and almost wish I could experience it again all from the beginning, knowing nothing. It's not long at all, can maybe just take you about 10 hours to finish it all, if that. But it's totally worth it.I would have paid $20 for this, no questions asked. Immediate buy, 10/10.

This game... this game.. this GAME..!!I can't even begin to describe how I feel about this game. I don't even want to in case I accidentally spoil something! The main point is that if you even like visual novels a TINY bit, you have to buy this game, it's amazing!! And if you like dragons/furries/reptiles/whatever, then you HAVE to buy this game. I would have paid $20 for this and it would have been worth it 100%I am too afraid to say anything else since I don't want to spoil anything, but please don't let the cover art or synopsis turn you away; if you even just like a good story and don't mind the visual novel format, you must own this game. There's a reason there are so many positive reviews, and they're all right on the money.BUY THIS GAME NOW. SPREAD THE WORD.TELL YOUR FRIENDS.12/10 would buy again

So let me start off by saying that I'm a bit biased when it comes to these types of visual novels. I don't play them as much as I used to anymore, but this one was one that I just had to pick up when I heard about it and saw the kickstarter for it.In short, it's one of those visual novels where there are 9 or so different people trapped in a place that's locked down for a certain number of hours, and they have to escape within a certain amount of time or else they die and etc. But there is so much more to it than that, I tell you hwut.Like I said I'm a bit of a sucker for these types of games, but depending on what kinds of stories and scenarios and cliches you like/are okay with, you may like this game as much as me, or you might just find many of the tropes and cliches kind of annoying. This is an anime visual novel, so the typical anime tropes will be here. I do find some of them kind of annoying, but it doesn't really get in the way of the good parts of the whole thing overall, in my opinion.I've heard that people thought that this game starts off slow, or it had a good premise but they feel if goes too slowly or there's not a good payoff in the end? And to that I say that it's somewhat true, but I believe the payoff is well worth it in the end. It has good characters, a good story, good plot, good twists.. I couldn't be happier. Like I said in my little review of the 3rd Zero Escape game, this is the type of game where I do look back on when I first played it and didn't know anything about the story or characters or all that, and I wish I could go back and replay it without knowing anything. So without rambling too much about nothing, I do recommend this game if you like visual novels. It was even recommended by the guy who made/wrote the 999/Zero Escape games, so that's basically all you need to know if it's good or not!! Definitely recommend.

It's alright, but it definitely wasn't the GRAND ENDING I was hoping for. The first two games were amazing and brilliant and I look back on them wishing that I could play them through again for the first time, but this game was just.. okay. Not terrible or horrible, but no where near as amazing as the first two games, in my opinion.A little disappointing to be perfectly honest, but still. It was alright.

This game has to be one of THE best games I have ever played in my entire life, and I am not exaggerating. If you haven't heard already, Undertale is a recently new RPG-type game that brings many new things to the genre. As the tagline of the game itself says, it is "a friendly RPG where no one has to get hurt," and that's true! Challenging it may be at times, but you can truthfully get through the entire game being good and not hurting anyone/anything, or you can be as mean as you like and just destroy anyone that gets in your way.Without spoiling too much, this game does feature choice and consequences in such a way that is a refreshing change from what we see normally from games that advertise that same thing. There's not really much consequence in choosing Option A or Option B, but it's more like how you play the game. If you play it a certain way, the characters might pick up on it, and in some cases, they may comment on how they feel you're progressing through the game, and the choices you've been making so far.The story is amazing, and frankly I'd be perfectly fine if this was just a game where you walk and listen to the story laid out before you, piece by piece. But the RPG elements do help in keeping things interesting and not boring to the player, as I'm sure it wouldn't be as interesting to some people without some fighting and action in it, along with you actually DOING things, rather than just mashing the Enter key while reading text. But still, the story itself is just so amazingly written and just so.. unique. You definitely need to play through it yourself to understand and fully appreciate the characters and the surprisingly complex story that is going on.The music is outstanding; catchy oldschool style chiptunes that'll be caught in your head for a while. The soundtrack itself is also worth the $10 price tag as well, if you choose to buy it separately. All in all, I can't gush about this game enough. It's short enough to where it won't take up too much of your time; I'd say about 5 hours or so for a normal one-time runthrough of the game, but it does encourage a second, or maybe third, runthrough if you so desire. This game will make you laugh, it'll make you tear up, it'll even make you eerily unsettled at some points too, I'd say! But mostly, it'll make you look back on it and reflect on how refreshingly new and different games like this can be. The best $10 I've ever spent.

First off, I just have to say that I thought this game was awesome <3  I'm a bit biased, since I'm a fan of visual novel/exploration type games, and this is one of them! It does kind of seem like a first person horror-esque game, but it is NOT that at all. A lot of people on the Steam Community who are talking about this game and "reviewing" it are mostly people who are upset that it's "boring" or a waste of money or whatever.I would recommend you get it on sale, because $20 does seem a bit steep, but I was able to grab it for $10, which I think is fair. The game is more of less just you walking around and exploring your family's new mansion house they've just moved into, and trying to find out what's going on with the family you've been away from for about a year or so.If you seem to enjoy a game's story more than gameplay, then I'm pretty sure you'll enjoy this game. If you're more into gameplay and you don't really care much for talking and reading and stuff like that, I'd advise you steer clear of this one; since the only "gameplay" in this game is walking, opening doors, and reading little notes and excerpts from books. To the rest of you who are interested, I recommend this game definitely! But try to get it on sale, if you can.

Holy crap I didn't think that I would like this game at all much, but it's just.. wow, I just love this game, haha.It's so awesome, but it's just a.. it's almost a shame how this game can have such a better.. "story" than many other games I've played. It's just.. I don't know how to put it into words, haha.It's not perfect, obviously, but oh my goddd the music is so great and it seems to fit so well. Originally played on 3DS, got Steam version via Humble Bundle.Very polished and good metroidvania with a solid cast of funny characters and tight, responsive controls and abilities. Game is legitimately fun and fun to explore. Music by Jake Kaufman is incredible, and has gorgeous pixel art. PC and console versions other than 3DS suffer from some art clash with resized assets, however. If you look past that, it's a pretty solid port of a really fun Metroidvania.
Great deal and great music, although there are missing tracks.

Sonic 4: Episode 1 feels like the product of a company trying to cash in on nostalgia, quickly duck taped together at the last minute on a very meager budget. The main physics, lifted right out of Sonic Rush, feel horrible. Sonic loses every bit of momentum as you let go of the control stick, and feels like he has a load of bricks in his shoes. The level design is horrid, constantly punishing you by throwing you into bottomless pits and with incredibly random enemy placement. Bosses are just reused from old classic 2D Sonic games, and the game looks and sounds horrible. Faux-Synthy music coupled with graphics that look like Donkey Kong Country on the SNES gone horribly wrong absolutely kill any sort of positive presentation the game has.Sonic 4: Episode 1 isn't really worth the time you can be spending just playing Sonic 1, 2 or 3K instead.

While the most glaring issues of Episode 1 were fixed in this follow-up, the game is still marred by incredibly janky and cheap level design, repetitive music with horrid instruments, and just a lack of soul. You're better off just buying the classics off Steam. They're half the price of this anywho.

It's different! As different as that one turret from Portal 2 who you probably saved from firey trash compactor-related doom.The Steam Controller is Valve's go at making a controller that bridges the gap between a traditional controller and a mouse and keyboard. Some games like platformers don't usually play well with a keyboard and mouse, and games like a first person shooter control with very mediocre results with a traditional controller. The Steam Controller attempts to make the line between input methods a little less thick. Instead of two analogue sticks and a d-pad, the Steam controller has two touch pads which are completely configurable. You can use the touchpads as a d-pad, a mouse, face buttons, and more. Underneath the touchpads are an analogue stick and the face buttons, placed in such a way that echoes the layout of the Wii U Pro Controller.The controller also makes cute noises and blips when you turn it on and off. This is probably it's greatest feature.You have your standard triggers and bumpers, but also two satisfying grips on the back which click in. These grips are probably what make this controller for me, as they can also be configured for anything and are super comfortable and easy to use; although they do need some getting used to. Also in the controller is a gyro sensor, which allows for tilt controls. I found myself using the tilt controls to aim up and down in first person shooters, after games like Splatoon have shown me how solid this set up is.My gripes with the Steam controller are few and do not completely break the product. The face buttons are a bit too small for my gargantuan thumbs, the analogue stick sometimes goofs up inputs, and you'll want to forget ever using any of these touchpads as a d-pad as the experience is very unpleasant (which could be a sale-killer for people who play fighting games on computers.)The Steam controller is a solid product that also feels super expiremental. While I really like the controller myself, I advise trying a friend's first before plunking down the $50.

Despite what some may have thought on initial release, Spore remains a golden game that never seems to fail to amuse and occupy. From the various wacky ideas, to the unique creation parts, the game itself has a longevity that has survived the test of time. In a way, it's a shame this game is slowly but surely dying out - as computers update, Spore becomes harder to run (crashing on death, graphical and camera control issues), but overall, the experience of Spore is one that is sublime in nature.I recommend it whole-heartedly, both to anybody curious, and to people who know but have yet to play.

A 17 year-long disappointment in the making.The list of issues I have with this game compared to the first could fill for the in-game wiki from the original's game. So much of this game shoes signs of being rushed and lacking polish. An utter grind that I could equate to a mobile game. All class and substance in-game has been cut down to the barest threads of satirical humour the original game had.It genuinely feels as if the game itself was designed for the mobile market - with 30+ minute long mission timers, to the endless cycle of needing money to spend money to get money, to the lockout system on the world map... I genuinely find this heartbreaking.There are hundreds if not thousands of community suggestions and bug reports being kept on a discord, reported by players, and it speaks volumes on the sheer lack of QA, polish, testing or development this game has undergone. I cannot stress this enough: just pick up the original. Disregard, ignore, and discard any ideas, thoughts, and nostalgia you have at the door if you're somehow still convinced this game is, by any means or metrics "fun and engaging".Shame on you Rebellion.

The only credible thing I can say about the game is that it's better when you decide to cheat. This game is devoid of entertainment, devoid of strategy, devoid of thought, and honestly, I would recommend nobody pick up this game except for the sole purpose of just getting a method of cheating or manipulating it. A $30 Powder clone in RNG-laden, rogue-like clothing. Do yourself a favour, and save your dollars.

When people comment on stories in videogames, or how well a game handles player engagement, I can think of no game other than Deus Ex. Having played it for quite some time now - a total of 31 hours - and having completed it, there is something incredibly special about this game.Being just 30 years away, Deus Ex can be prophetic at times, if a little bizarre with how it handles some of it's story elements. Yet roaming the streets, there ware innovations already being worked on bringing us closer to the level of technology we see in Deus Ex.Yet, the gameplay is the only part I can fault, Deus Ex is a brutally hard game for it's time. As soon as you can, I would recommend levelling up the Rifle Skill and playing with a Silenced Sniper Rifle. The Sniper is an instant takedown as long as you hit the head of your target. Staying low and in cover, picking off targets one by one starts to feel a little unfair at times until you realise just how brutal the game can be, with just a few stray enemies able to take you down as if you were made of straw and they were an oncoming hurricane. Definitely one of my favourite games of all time regardless. I will come back to it one day, but for now, I urge all who have yet to play Deus Ex one good attempt. It is worth your time. Coming into the game, I expected the depth of a tycoon game. Planning and plotting, strategy, and above all, a solid throughline. What I got was a game focused on pressing tab and right clicking a bunch. The easiest way to win is simple, mindless mashing. This is going to be the first game I refund on Steam simply because of the lack of complexity in the game, how simple it is just to swarm and overturn police as protestors. The campaign is a joke too, being short, barely ten minutes of gameplay each, as you spam tab to quickly flip between protestor groups. It's the dominant strategy for peaceful protesting. The megaphone being the trump card in the arsenal, as well as the Social Media push being a cheap and easy way to throw bodies at the cops. The molotov cocktails seemed to not do anything, nor did any of the aggressive weapons, and being aggressive seemed to bring no reward anyway. While I haven't tried the police, this is the first game where I don't even want to give it more effor than I gave it. I feel even if I did play the police, it'd be more of the same - tab and right click, be peaceful and just push/wave assault them backwards. Maybe it'd be a little more difficult due to the way the mechanics work (if there are any outside of spamming people at the objective), but overall, why should I bother doing more of the same?The graphics are unimpressive as well. Blurry, grimey, unpleasant - while it SHOULD fit the tone of the game, it's just dismal and a mish-mash. The cutscenes are paced and animated as if they're supposed to be real humans, but it's just pixelly vignettes that look choppy at worst and contorted at best. Nothing stands out, nothing looks like what it's supposed to be.All in all, I give this game a 2.4/10. Poor graphics, bad controls, mash mechanics and overall little replayability. Save your money and go by Tooth and Tail instead, because in all honesty, it's actually more of a RIOT than this game is. Civil Unrest? More like Civil Detest.

Factorio is a game of excessive labour - think of it as a model railway you have to build over a long, drawn-out process, assembling all you need to, buying the pieces you don't have, slotting everything together to form a fantastical and rejuvenating experience for your train to go on. The soul of Factorio exists in the feeling of accomplishment you get when you align everything as perfectly as you can, and all the components to automate that thing that once took you a good ten minutes of waiting to craft suddenly is pumped out on a timely manner, to be absconded onto a train's caboose and rolled to some far-off production line, deposited into another machine or safety box, to be used in another process far beyond your tiny human hands. It can be messy, intricate, chaotic, organised - Factorio is guaranteed a game that will give you the feeling of "What shall I do next?" after you've finished the production for science vials, and leave you hungry for more. I recommend this game highly, especially if you have multiple friends - to either compete against in organising a factory that can produce the most, or to work with one another, and have a mad dash to the finish together. Even as a solo experience, I can heartily recommend the game to those whom need to have that itch of watching pieces of a jigsaw puzzle slot together, for I can assure you, Factorio delivers an experience akin to it in spades.

This is an absolutely fantastic beat-em-up that fans of all kinds will enjoy - those who have lots of beat-em-up experience, those who are huge Turtles fans, and even just people who are interested but haven't played a game like these before. Gameplay is fantastic and offers a lot for all skill levels, and there's plenty of content to sink your teeth into. There's a good amount of challenge in the "Cool" difficulty option, which is basically just the regular difficulty, with a Hard mode being present for those seeking a challenge.The music and visuals speak for themselves. Tee Lopes absolutely killed it on the soundtrack here, and there's a lot of other artists that did some absolutely fantastic work here too. The visuals are a joy to the eye, and character animations are full of life and lots of fun.Netcode is fantastic, though it can be a bit janky. It syncs up the most important things such as hits/health, but some attacks can be a pain. Multiplayer in general is very fun - the difficulty gets ramped up, but having way more people makes things much more manageable. It's a chaotic kind of fun that becomes an absolute joy to play with friends, laughing things off and playing with one another.The only real gripe I personally have is some bosses being just okay, but that's something almost every beat-em-up suffers from. They aren't bad or tedious or anything of the sort, they're kind of just okay. The main levels themselves more than make up for this, it's just that bosses won't blow you away or anything like that. Some are slightly annoying, but you make do.This is an absolutely fantastic game and I cannot reccomend it enough if you are even SLIGHTLY interested. Even if you've never played a beat-em-up, even if you don't care for the TMNT, this is an absolutely STELLAR game and it's something that can be enjoyed by absolutely everybody. It's an absolute treat, and for a price like this, it's a REALLY good pickup. You'll definitely get your times worth, especially if you're someone who really enjoys replaying games to experience different characters, different challenges you place on yourself, etc.

Vrchat oh boi Vrchat, there's a reason this is my most played game. this game has probably been one of the influential games in my life since halo. in vrchat you are able to meet people from all over the world from all sorts of communities. vrchat has let me experience the heart of meme, anime, brony, and furry communities and others learning alot about internet culture i didn't know much about in the first place while making some of the best friends i've ever had. i've been playing since before the knuckles meme hype and the friends i've even made even back then still talk to me today we've even made an effort to meet in real life. vrchat has a very welcoming community and i would recommend it to anyone who has a hard time making friends in their area it maybe intimidating it may be hard but you can make friends in this game and make real connections with others. the experience is multiplied ten fold when you finally get vr. being able to go to all these worlds crafted by the community in either an avatar you made yourself or an avatar the community crafted for public use is an experience. that alone about this game has resurfaced my love for 3d modeling. before this game i had no idea howto use blender or unity but thanks to the community i've learned all this and able to use this for more than just personalizing myself in vrchat. i hope you all can find the time to play this amazing game and make yourself some friends.

Whether or not it's the best, this is certainly the most audacious Monster Hunter game. World takes a dramatic leap into a look, feel, and size that feels truly new, simultaneously staying true to the series‚Ä?ideals by maintaining the addictive loop of combat, intimidating monsters and meaningful upgrades that fans love. The sheer depth and commitment required is still intense, but it clearly isn‚Äôt Capcom‚Äôs aim to court a casual crowd. This is as all-consuming and incredible a ride as ever.

The hook of Borderlands 2, the very reason that I found myself thinking about it when I worked or tried to fall asleep, is the loot. Guns, ammo, character skins, grenade mods, class mods -- there‚Äôs always something just a bit better, something you so desperately didn‚Äôt even know you needed until you found it in Borderlands 2. Just like Diablo or a number of other action RPGs, the hunt for loot becomes intoxicating because of the tiny rush you get each time a rare colored item spills out of a chest or is dropped by a recently slain enemy. Every firefight and the intense boss battle becomes all the more rewarding, because, though you might die a few times and want to crush something near you in real life, it suddenly feels like everything is going to be OK when you‚Äôre blasting away enemies with a newly looted gun.Guns really do make up the bulk of the loot, and that‚Äôs great because you‚Äôre going to spend most of your time in Borderlands 2 staring down a gun sight. No matter the quest, at some point something or someone is getting pounded with lead. Thankfully, snappy shooting and lots of environmental hazards combine with each class‚Äôs unique ability to turn every skirmish into a playground. You simply have to decide the best -- or most entertaining -- way to kill everyone.

Once i started i couldn't stop. The art and music really bring this game to life.!!! I love it and will play it over and over. :) The story takes many differnt tiwst and turns!!!! you are sure to love it! I rate it 10/10!!!

WELCOME TO VRCHAT!A place of joy, happiness, and turns you gay/trans/furry/weeb! Where the game was rigged against you, and now it wants to make sure you never play it again!The devs have made the executive decision to nuke a vast majority of their players off the servers with the implementation of Easy Anti-Cheat! What this means:Linux will be gone, because EAC hates itAnyone who gets caught with a mod, hack, or "cheat" will be permanently banned from the servers without a way to get back on with that account (unless you jump through hoops with specific clients).Rippers, Crashers, and anyone with a malicious client will have free reign to torment VRC, because EAC will block those with preventative measures from uploading their programs safely.Those who want QoL mods will have to go elsewhere.The disabled community is going to have a rotten time communicating.The avatar/world/asset creators are going to have to jump through more hoops to not get their content banned. They will also lose a good CHUNK of their livelihoods because that revenue will be gone.These are a few of what's gonna happen, and once EAC goes live, there's going to be an exodus of players migrating to Chillout VR and Neos. Because, let's face it, when have the VRC Devs listened to people that aren't holding their purse strings shut?So get off your butts and MAKE them listen! Get off VRC a stop your subscription!

This is a wonderful walking simulator where you get to tell the game "I'm still alive," and the game shouting "BET!" Though, if you survive long enough, the game throws a hissy fit and sends its delete key at you.

For a game that touts about making decisions, it seems to railroad you quite often. For example, you'll have to go find a guy named Banner because the government wants him. He's rescued, then his wife is kidnapped, and your character promises to go rescue her. Whereas the ship's AI states that it's better to sacrifice one to save many. This is sound logic, but what does the game do? Sends you to the next coordinates to go rescue her.Would have loved to have seen more interactions and have the decision to just say NO to the guy's face, then drop him off at the Republic's HQ. "But how would the other systems open up, if you don't mount a rescue?!" Simple. Open up the system as a whole, and let folks figure it out.I can see how the beginning you'd need some railroading to point people in the right direction, but the game is about making decisions. And I want to be an evil bastard.

At the time of writing this, if you blitz through the game, there's about 2-3 hours of enjoyment. If you go for all of the blueprints? Another 4-5 hours of grinding on top of that. Want the materials for every perk in the game? Probably another hour into the pot, because you get them alongside the blueprints.Overall, you'll be spending about 8-10 hours worth of grinding through about 17ish levels (more to come) after spending 2-3 hours customizing your mech until you think it's perfect. Then spending more time with the newer pieces until you're FINALLY satisfied, only to find out that there's an issue and you don't like that ONE piece on the mech, and have to go in, find it, then find the piece you want. Possibly recoloring it to a different shade of blue, because the presets aren't what you wanted...You get the idea, right?

This game is a solid NO from me.I started my journey of love with Destiny 2 toward the end of Season of Opulence, and enjoyed it up to them starting their vaulted content with Beyond Light. They removed a LOT of content, like the grind on Mars that was an absolute joy when you needed to Masterwork an exotic. Then you had to swap to the moon when no one showed up because the moon was the newest place to grind, but I digress.I got it that vaulting the zones was part of the story, but double backing some of the weapons? Why not ALL of them? I have a Truth in my vault that was used to make me fall in love with hand cannons, as well as despising them in PvP. It's capped at 1100, so I can't use it anymore. Same goes for all the ritual weapons that I spent hours trying to grind for, or the strike based weapons like The Militia's Birthright that were painful, and you had to pray to RNGesus that it'll pop out.Having spent well over 2k hours, both the original launcher and on Steam, I can honestly say that I'm tired of the game. It was a great place to grind, meet new people, make new friends, and rage at the raids. The game allows for people to drone, and that's always great when you want to shut off your brain for a couple of hours, but they're going to vault two more zones next month, as well as a LOT more weapons and armor.If you're a new player, or someone returning, wait until February 22 to see how it is.

One of the few games to really lose track of time in. Thought I was playing for a few minutes, turned out to be an hour. Highly recommend, especially if you want to ask yourself, "It's only been a few minutes, why the hell am I so sweaty?!"

TL;DR: Another Veteran gets pissed, rambles on about the "good ol' days" of Robocraft, and won't be returning even IF they decide to roll back to one of their older versions.I have another ~200 or so hours on their launcher, as well as the 410 hours here, and have been playing on and off since it first appeared in Early Access. Meaning, I've played around when it was just wheels, hovers, and flyers. Not real sure if it was planes, choppers, or both, though.Thing is, I can remember a time when I first got my hovers and was excited about buzzing around the battlefield that way. However, if they weren't spaced out, you could find yourself floating upside down with an unprotected underside. This was all before the much needed flipping mechanism they installed, then revamped to four seconds instead of ten, as well as no training rooms or what not. Just simple TDM all day every day.Then the insect legs came out, and boy was everyone happy. So much so, there were many who completely failed, but was still fun. Not to mention the fun little designs people created with them. Spiderbots. Spiderbots everywhere. Sure, there was the odd scorpion thrown into the mix, but I remember more spiders than them.This was about the time I left for a few months, and came back to find MEGABOTS. Oh boy, what a train wreck that was when it started. The Megabots before the epic ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• up with FJ were more artsy than naught, but you have to understand something. The art bots I very much enjoyed were VERY squishy. The reason why was very simple: Each block had different HP, with silver-blue and black-red/green being the highest, and white/glass being the lowest. Yes, glass cubes were easily bought back then, but would drop your framerate to Nil if blown up. Another way to drop the FPS was to attach your bot with as many flags as humanly possible. The more you have, the less amount of bots you'd see on the battlefield, because everyone with crappy computers were lagging real bad.That was a fun time, and I really do miss those days. What with grinding for TP (talent or technical points, not real sure which) to grab that much needed weapon, block, or what have you. Then grind for RP just so you can buy the much needed blocks to allow you into the next tier. That's right folks, I said TIER, and there were 10 of them, 11 with Megabots.Each tier had its own set of blocks needed for you to stay, or else you'll end up in the next one with crap guns, blocks, and armour. Not to mention the fact that if your pilot seat is exposed, and gets nicked by a small shot, you were dead and could only whine about it. There was no "wait ten seconds to be instantly healed", only you, in the middle of nowhere, waiting for death. Sure. There were healers around this time, but they were more focused on the Mega and not your sorry ass.Then came the "The Pit", which was okay, I guess. Never really got into it, and still don't. Would rather work as a team, rather than duke it out with four to nine other bots. However, they had their own set of problems. Such as instantly healing after getting to the top of the board. There was an exploit in there, where a person was able to have a continuous heal added to their bots if they made it just right. I'm not one to say how, but they patched it out within a couple of months.Afterwards came "Challenge Battle", but I'm pretty sure its referred to as "Battle Arena". Again, it wasn't my thing, even though it gave everyone a chance at better tactics and strategies. Not to mention the increased revenue for completing such a thing, and the introduction to callouts on the minimap. This also came with a bug, more of an exploit really. Where one team with superior firepower would "farm" the other team for points whilst waiting at their base. They wouldn't touch the main crystal, and simply went for the people who spawned in. Pretty sure there's a comic about it floating around Reddit with this.Really, though, this was a fun time to play Robocraft, until the majour ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• everyone knows about. Such as the removal of Tiers (BIG MISTAKE, FJ), removing the way people gained their blocks, modules, armour, etc, and shoving everyone into what they called "Battle Ranking". Went away for a month, came back, and found it to be horrid. Then again, I stuck around just to see what else they did.What did they bring? Why, new weapons, armour, and modules of course. not to mention the removal of Megabots. I love Megas, and had two; one SMG and one Plasma. I miss them both, but FJ doesn't want them, and if they say "No", there's not a DAMN we can do about it beyond writing these reviews.Folks, the thing is, I'm not going to recommend this game to ANYONE. If you want to try it out, go right on ahead. The game had its ups and downs, but now its just copying CS;GO and other first person shooters with their loot crates. Not to mention the fact that they've stopped talking to us over on Reddit after all this ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• popped into existence. If they decided to roll back to their previous versions of the game, not many of us would look twice. They've ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• up real big this time.PS: At the time of this review, I've about three months of Premium left on my account.

Ever played Armored Core 4, or For Answer, and you get the option of giving every mech out there infinite flight? That's exactly how it is in this game. Just like in Armored Core, you get a lock-on feature, and just like in AC, it's annoying, but useful.Pros:-Fast paced-Reminds me of Armored Core-Guns, Rockets, LOTS of explosionsCons:-Only two Acts at this time-Lock-on feature zooms in too much-ZERO customization-No way to upgrade/buy new weaponsHonestly, it really does remind me of Armored Core, but unlike it, I'm stuck with one mech for a couple of chapters, then I get shoved into a more nimble mech with six or seven different weapons, and it's just a headache trying to figure out how to utilize them to the fullest. I would like to suggest a sort of tutorial where you could try each and every one. Granted, a few are self explanatory, but the others require more detail.EDIT:So, I finally got off my ass long enough to hop back onto Project Nimbus, only to find it to be a chaotic mess. Good gods, the second act starts off with the Chinese, then gravitates a little towards the Americans, then forces you into the Russian's side of things, and finally brings you back to the first girl from Act 1. There's little room for character development because of this, which annoyed me to no end.With Armored Core you have, at the very least, the ability to pick which path you'd like to follow. Whereas PN simply drops you into the hot seat of whatever point of view they wish for you to be a part of. It just feels too damn rushed, in my own opinion.I'm glad the developers put in a way to change out mechs, but there's STILL zero customisations when it's all said and done. By the way, that's only towards the middle of the second act, and nowhere else in the game.I don't know, folks. If there was a "Meh" rating, I'd give it instead of saying yes or no in recommending the game. I'll keep it at a "Yes" for now, though, but my personal rating for the game dropped to 6/10 for lack of character development.

Great Turn Based Strategy game. The best way that I can describe it is this: Fire Emblem mixed with Civ and Aliens. This fantastic game gets even better with advancing technologies such as the Meld in the expansion, which lets your soldiers be genetically augmented or become MECH soldiers. Your soldiers are very customizable, however you cannot change their class. I give it an 9.7/10.

This game has no redeeming values. The picture you see on the store page is the entire game, and you can beat it in a few minutes. You launch it, hit start, find 7 memes and 3 radios, then shoot giant hitler and giant stalin. The memes are actually quite bad too. Interacting with them is also flawed, as I'll have to spam E and then aim and spam E and hope I grab one. One of the memes is actually Greta Thunberg with a hitler photoshop. There is also poorly implemented copyrighted content, such as Ultimate, by Denzel Curry and Roundabout, by Yes. Do yourself a favor and avoid this game, it was likely made by an edgy teen who just learned how to use Unity engine.

This is solely negative for the horrible online multiplayer experience. Horrible netcode lead to horrible rubber banding and disconnects, no matter who was hosting. After a while, it became near impossible to progress due to a multitude of bugs. For example, I was opening a chest, and even when I walked away from it, the "opening" text remained on screen, and I wasn't allowed to open said chest. The worst part of all is disconnecting when in the crafting/stats menu. You can't leave it, and must alt+f4 out of the game. Now, you might think you can just save frequently, but when the game disconnects, host migration occurs, and only the original host can save by sleeping in a bed. So, if you experience host migration, you can't save the game afterwards in case of a crash or anything else.It would be fun if we didn't face some error every 15 minutes.

You are Doom Guy, and the story is a reason for you to kill aliens in a gruesome way. Very classic and enjoyable PvP, no sprinting, just shooting, jumping, and armor health and ammo around. Very fast paced.
As of right now only Episode 1 is released.Let me just say, this might be better than the first, just because it builds so much on the first.Must buy if you've played the first.

A quick yet compelling experience without a single real word. Bonds grow between the brothers and you watch their adventure uinfold as you hunt for a cure for their father's sickness. Along the way you meet a few individuals who will help you, each a very interesting creature. This game has great visuals, powerful storytelling, and some of the mopst unique gameplay I've ever experienced. The only flaw is the difficulty of controlling two characters simultaneously, although even if you do struggle like I did, there are no "intense" parts where you have to quickly use each character at the same time. I cannot say much more without spoiling, but this is definitely worth a play.8/10

When I started this game I was awestruck. The intro mission is fantastic, the music and area set up a wonderful atmosphere. I was expecting a fantastic story like its predecessor, but with more action and guns. Once the intro sequence is over and you have your enemy and goal, the game turns to poo. I was so excited to go after the antagonist, but that desire faded quickly. I was met with an entirely different game almost, as the story seemed to lie dormant and every mission was a "Kill people in X building" or "Destroy X amount of things at location Y." A variation between those two objectives and a few locations makes the entire middle portion of the game a complete bore. Think Skyrim radiant quests, but imagine of those quests only showed up in towns and cities, and that they aren't side quests, but the entire story in the game. The end pretty much picks up where the intro left off, and completes Lincoln's story. If you watch the first hour or two of gameplay and the last hour on youtube, you won't have missed a thing. The only thing you'll miss is the introduction to your three gang bosses. 4/10, Great intro and conclusion, and that's about it. Visuals are muddy and hard to run, needs work on functionality, and more repetitive than Assassin's Creed 1.

6/10.This game is funky and fresh. Imagine Gone Home with humor and a silly adventure. It's a fantastic game... But only if you are able to get past the abundant usage of the words "stupid", "idiot", and "garbage".  The game would've easily been an 8/10, but the constant use of those words became near unbearable at a certain point. If they updated the game with a new voice actor and footstep sounds for a certain character, it would be so much better. You may think I'm being a bit extreme, but the combination of those words is used in nearly every sentence. If you can tolerate that, it is quite an enjoyable game.
It's free and took me 7 minutes, including messing around. You could've probably beat this game in the time it took to read all these reviews if you found this one. Play it.

I started out thinking this was gonna be a decent experience, finding out info on people using Orwellian tactics, and that's about it. I was kinda wrong. You don't have access to everything from the get-go. People start to cover their traces when they're up to no good.You are a contractor for Orwell, a government surveillance agency as an outside contractor. Yoor focus is to find evidence against a terrorist group and make sure they can no longer bomb people and places. You extract data from a variety of sources, articles, private messages between users (You need to find out their phone numbers/emails yourself) and access thier personal devices (You'll need a device ID for that though, which may or may not be hard to find). You tap phone calls and messages to learn about each character and their role in the story, and you can decide their fates.Here's the catch: your superiors can only see what you upload to them. You decide what they can and can't see.The first episode is more of a tutorial than anything, then episode 2 serves as an intro, and 3, 4, and 5 is where the story really takes off. The finale left me blown away, and I am definitely looking foward to the next game by these developers.If you want a great short story for a lazy day (or lazy days), check this out.

This game seems really difficult at first, then it will seem super easy, then it will be difficult once more when you face the pros.It's a great team game with a great community, this is a game everyone should have in their library.The devs are always releasing tons of free updates that add a multitude of great stuff too, you'd be crazy not to buy this.

Journey was a very fun overall experience. I was extremely excited by another game like The Under Presents, where they sneak in multiplayer with barely any communication, drop you into a strange and unknown world and let you figure the rest out.What I was VERY disappointed by was the fact there is basically no multiplayer hub. Games like this desperately need it to add replayability. If it just had a hub with some secrets, puzzles and other cool things to explore, where many people could get together and socialise, it would be perfect. The fact it's missing hurts the game and it's community greatly.

WOW!? bene qua non √® piu cosi il tutto e stato ridotto a registrazioni vocali, uno snake praticamente muto, e le emozioni sono fittizie perch√® scatenate dalla comparsa di personaggi che i vecchi giocatori conoscono o conosceranno (dipende la punto di vista)molto bene nei capitoli precedenti.In conclusione questo metal gear non doveva esser cosi ma molto pi√π elaborato sotto tutti i punti di vista, ma √® stato solo la vittima di un travagliato divorzio tra Konami e Kojima, risultato? una vera e propria gemma grezza che non briller√† mai perch√® la creativit√† e sempre pi√π schiava del commercio.

Painkiller: ResurrectionBeh volevo aspettare di finire tutta la saga per recensirla con calma e valutando magari differenze fra i vari capitoli, ma qui il fatto √® grave e magari recensendolo prima salver√≤ qualche povero giocatore che si √® messo in testa di provare questa oscenit√†, in realt√† troverete parecchie recensioni che vi sconsigliano di commettere l'errore di comprarlo e giocarlo ed io le avevo pure lette prima di iniziarlo, ma  sono un sadico non seguite il mio esempio.Bene vorrete sapere qual' √® il problema immagino, beh:- Porting fatto male e fin qui nessuna novit√†, questo √® un problema che affligge quasi tutta la serie, si ma questo ha qualcosa di speciale con i suoi crash random, oppure perdita di salvataggi o meglio ancora l'impossibilit√† di caricare i salvataggi rapidi dandoti un bel FATAL ERROR- Mappe penose e sconnesse sono talmente fatte male che nemici e addirittura boss rimangono incastrati in qualche punto,  esteticamente poi sono veramente orribili- Doppiaggio italiano fatto peggio del buon caro vecchio leone di lernia nello zoo di 105, e poi un ammazzademoni che quando vuol essere scurrile usa "cacchio"! Ridicolo.....- Beh trama scema, dura 1/3 in confronto gli altri painkiller(non badate al mio time di gioco 2-3 ore sono saltate rifacendo livelli e provando a risolvere i numerosi bug),in poche parole salvatevi, fa schifo!!!!

Stories: The Path of Destinies √® un gioco che mi ha rapito nonostante la sua semplicit√† e magari avendolo cominciato senza particolari aspettative, peccato che l'euforia iniziale √® andata scemando dopo averlo finito 4/5 volte, run necessarie per trovare il vero finale, ora non ricordo con esattezza ma calcolate che questo gioco ha circa 24 finali alternativi ed √® qui che il gioco perde colpi, a seconda delle scelte tu scopri percorsi alternativi ma non sono abbastanza dopo un po diventer√† noioso e ripetitivo negli scenari,  in conclusione il gioco poteva avere ben pi√π potenziale con qualche ambiente aggiuntivo e magari qualche finale in meno, accompagnato da un  un sistema di upgrade delle abilit√† e dell' equipaggiamento meno basilare, peccato...

Saints Row: The Third non offre certo tutte le infinite opzioni che pu√≤ darti un GTA, ma √® un valido titolo da giocare (magari in coop) il punto di forza di questo gioco √® la demenzialita del gameplay stesso ma sopratutto di armi, gadget, o vestiti (ammesso che tu voglia indossarli)Il gioco sul piano tecnico ha qualche piccolo difetto per quanto riguarda il salvataggio automatico in coop o la sincronizzazione con il tuo compagno di gioco (solo in auto) ma niente di particolarmente rilevantePer concludere, consiglio di giocarci in coop cosi vi divertirete il doppio e ovviamente di acquistare la versione full quando questa √® in saldo

Mi Far√≤ tanti nemici ma molti pi√π amici partendo dal fatto che finita la trilogia, resident evil non √® stato mai pi√π lo stesso, per me il 4 √® stato l'inizio della fine di una delle saghe che seguo fin da piccolo,ho giocato a TUTTi i capitoli della serie da buon appassionato, ma col 4/5/&6 ormai mi ero rassegnato al degrado che col capitolo 6 aveva raggiunto il suo apice, poi arriva RE7... la capcom preme il tasto reset e ci da un capitolo in prima persona ridandoci per√≤ finalmente il tocco horror e i buoni e cari vecchi enigmi che caratterizzavano i primi capitoli, tutto accompagnato da una buona trama, doppiaggio in italiano,grafica eccellente e chi pi√π ne ha pi√π ne metta.Ovviamente non √® un titolo perfetto, sotto l'aspetto tecnico necessita di un Pc che sa il fatto suo se si vuol godere a pieno dell'aspetto grafico senza cali di frame o freeze random, per il resto sono tutti difettucci passabili ma rientrano in un discorso di trama e non voglio anticipare niente a nessuno, concludendo con una mia personale ed ultima piccola critica su questo titolo, sarebbe stato perfetto se ci fossero stati i classici zombie al posto degli esseri presenti nell'intero gioco8/10 ragazzi Resident evil √® tornato

Allora, non voglio farvi la una delle solite recensioni tecniche, vi dico solo che left for dead 2 √® il primo gioco che ho comprato su steam e ancora oggi a differenza di anni mi diverto come la prima volta,questo anche se si puo giocare da soli (cosa molto triste) √® l ideale da giocare con amici sia in co-op che in pvp, i server sono sempre pieni di gente, non ha bisogno di chiss√† quali caratteristiche perch√® gira bene anche su pc vecchiotti,inoltre il workshop √® pieno di mod che aiutano a variare il gioco anche sotto il punto di vista estetico con skin di armi personaggi ecc. e anche con mappe del tutto nuovo, tutto questo alla misera cifra di 4 euro (scontato) quindi vi dico... state ancora qui a leggere??? COMPRATELO!!!!

Kholat presenta una grafica guidata dal motore Unreal 4, essa seppur presentando un abiente dal colore base bianco e da un ambiente completamente aperto al contrario di molti giochi appartenenti al genere horror riesce comunque a trasmettere uno stato di tensione, grazie anche all'aiuto delle musiche e dai rumori che si miscelano perfettamente con l'ambiente circostante, con ci√≤ il gioco si presenta sicuramente bene.La storia ci viene largamente anticipata all' inizio e durante il gioco in pratica non ci rimarr√† molto da capire, il gameplay consiste semplicemente nel raccogliere informazioni sugli eventi che circondano kholat, esso si svolge esplorando i vari sentieri orientandosi solamente con una mappa e una bussola che siamo costretti ad usare spesso per non perderciIn conclusione seppur io sia un giocatore che perde tempo nell' esplorazione il gioco in tutto √® durato poco pi√π di 3 ore, troppo poco per gli standard odierni e anche quelli passati, una storia a mio parere senza ne capo ne coda, si salva solo un po graficamente ma purtroppo la grafica non √® la prima e neanche la seconda cosa che guardo in un gioco, considerando che da un p√≤ di tempo desideravo giocare questo titolo sono rimasto veramente deluso

This is basically gonna be a first impression review, but this game is pretty shallow so I think it holds up regardless! The characters are super cute, and while some of them are kinda REALLY cliche, the designs are mostly quirky enough to keep you interested, and the fighting styles actually vary a lot more than I thought. Although, some of the characters kinda feel a bit clunky to control, you're sure to find one you really like and stick with her. The story is pretty short, but it IS repeatable with different characters, which keeps the novelty value up. I don't advise taking this game too seriously, it's more fun to mess around with and play as a super-casual saccharine fighting game than a serious esport contender.

It's fun, and it will teach you the basics of playing guitar. But it's obviously not the all-encompassing tool that it claims to be; you're gonna need to spend time practicing and mastering techniques outside of the game if you want to be a legit guitar player. Regardless, it's relaxing and can teach you to play some good songs. The DLC selection is extensive but pretty bad imo, if you're into pop/country music and 50s-80s music you'll have a good time, but if you're into more modern or interesting music you're gonna want to get CDLC.

A super colourful and enjoyable rhythm game. Definitely recommend buying the DLC if you like this game, because it's well worth it and the majority of the really good songs can be found there. I only have two real problems: I play on a TV, so it's a little out of sync and lacks any calibration settings, so I'd like to see that added in the future. The other problem is the 8-bit style theme is pretty much impossible to play any of the more difficult songs on due to its weird scrolling speed, which is a shame because it's such a cool looking theme.

It truly shocked me to my core when I discovered the existence of this game. I never thought, in my lifetime, I would possibly witness a gaming experience so magnificently flawless and breathtaking. Garfield Kart captured my heart and continues to invade my thoughts, every waking and sleeping moment. My life is over.

Tries a bit too hard. Reminds me of a creepypasta game like that SONIC.EXE trash, but with a bit of a weeb flair on it. I think the game could have been a lot better if they rolled with the realistic psychologically disturbing storyline, instead of it descending into pointless 4th wall-breaking nonsense. Also the ending is just laughable.

Greatest game in human history. Anyone who dismisses the idea of playing this game is utterly insane. Beautiful characters and a compelling storyline set you up for one of the most magnificent things you'll ever experience in your life. The characters will totally envelop you into the atmosphere and keep you coming back for that sweet dose of bartender action.

FIRST, MY REFERRAL CODE: 7497be5f2c3d16b4The game is excelent(that tutorial is the best i have ever seen in a game) but i have some suggestions:- Add the possibility to play arena matches against friends.- Add a button in the phobies card to show the name of each stat. Normally people forget the tutorial and, atleast for me, its hard to understand the meaning of some stats, for example, the stat with the electricity icon in it, the stat on the right of the damage number on some phobies,etc...- Try to explain a little better some stats, for example, the "Disease" stat from smiley, etc.. (and btw, why is halitosis an hability instead of an basic attack ?)- Add some lore to the phobies.- Increase the amount of tears that we can win per day so that we dont have to win 4 games (that would, without any limitation, win us 1200 tiers) to win just 1000 tears.- Show us some percentages on the packs.(i know that the coffee ones are posted on the website but showing the percentages of ALL packs ingame would be 10 times better and, correct me if im wrong, it would probably not change much in design)- On the "boosts" tab, add some text showing that the 4 boxes on the top are the active boosts.(I was really confused for a while)- On the daily double (i dont know if there is a cap for the coffee beans), either remove the coffee beans icon from the box logo or add the value of beans getting capped on the description.- Sort the portraits on shop by currency and add a button to hide the owned ones.- Add some choice into the jacks, for example, instead of having 8 normals + 1 diamond, we could have 16 normals + 2 diamonds but we would only be able to collect 8 normals + 1 diamond, showing the rest of the choices at the end. (That would be good to implement with the daily double, removing the need to reset the jacks page and adding some hype on the players to by the daily double, because they would already know the contents of the daily double jacks)- Get the frenemies out of the "More" tab, so it will be easier to access and prettier on the home screen.- I would switch out the "settings" and "news" tabs, because the gear icon is super specific and the mouth icon is hard to identify as related to news.- Add an way to continue in a battle when we finish a turn, instead of needing to wait for the other player to finish their round(making it easier for anyone that want to finish a specific battle instead of having to play the whole normal queue of rounds)- Add some cool animation when entering the menus (play, arena, the stairs, fears, etc..)- Add some visual eastereggs, for example, clicking on the door, on bottom of the games counter, could drop the door to the floor, show the sum of all fears hidding behind it and then the sum of all fears would pick the door and put it back into the normal spot.- Show what we won on each jack.- Add some lines to the mouth making jokes about the player for trying to do stupid things on the menu.- Making it possible to drag Vendy around.- Add some BIG limitation to the Pay to Win system. (its the only way this game will last for more than a year! The pay2win players are already leaving the game because they cannot find no one on the arena and the f2p players leave out of frustration because of the difference in stats comparing to the p2w players)- Add some skins for the phobies (would probably give you the chance to remove a bit of the pay to win scheme)- Add some optional commercial videos(at least on the mobile version) to combat the pay to win system. Please, if you do add this videos, remove some/all of the p2w system.- Add some more AI player names! Im tired of playing against the same AI player.- Add a better ranking system, so that the f2p players don't play against p2w players every game.- Make weekly or atleast monthly balancing of the cards.- Add an option to change the langague (cmon, it is already implemented! It only needs the frontend)
