The most imaginative and inventive strategy game out there...But also the hardest to work out what you have to do to even remotely be good. One of those games you'll be googling guides and build orders for just so you can survive against default AI. Campaign tutorial is buttonology rather than teaching strategy.

If you play RTS games for the campaign - you'll LOVE this game. The campaign has such amazing production values that you feel like you are playing some kind of documentary and completing missions gives you access to informational videos about various medieval elements from castle construction to the development of the crossbow and many more. However, if you play RTS games for in-depth multiplayer gameplay, this one is a let down. 1v1 games are passable, but in team games you will find that the civilisation uniqueness and balance forces certain play-styles. Such that if you are playing against the Franks you HAVE to go for spearman first because they will ALWAYS get early knights. If playing as the English, you will ALWAYS go for early longbows so anyone playing against you will always have to go for cavalry and so on. Multiplayer games therefore lack depth, and inevitably devolve into spam of a few late game units, stone walls, wonders and cannons. I've never played a multiplayer game where I have found I have had to pivot to a different unit type knowing that it will make 'enough' of a difference. Aside from the lacking multiplayer, the game is lacking so many *basic* features of any modern RTS and even features that have existed in Age of Empires games that are over 15 years old!!! Scores, way-points, matchmaking, map making, spectator features.In summary, aside from the campaign, this game is something of a let-down. Worth a purchase on sale for I'd say 50% off. ¬£20 is the most I'd recommend paying.

I can't recommend a game about free-running where you expect your experience to be slick and smooth and yet...- Controls are inconsistent- Environments don't flow- Combat is a chore- Pacing is off because of retries- Irritating movementI wanted to like the game and I like the premise, but it loses its charm very quickly when you are trying to battle inconsistencies. Like the Ori games where you have those "chase" sequences, they would be amazing if you didn't have to retry them from copious deaths.This game, your deaths will arise from experimentation and plain inconsistencies. Where's this "AMAZING GAME" I was told about?
A good fun game when you can play a private game with friends. Shame you can't do that any more without giving away ludicrous amounts of money. Not worth downloading any more.

Shadow of the Tomb Raider - a fitting end to this trilogy, but something feels like the stage we got to at the end of this game could have come sooner...SynopsisSotTR starts off with Lara as the person we know, finding tombs unknown by her adversaries, also know as Trinity. This isn't really a spoiler either as you're the standard villain. But it feels good - you're thrust straight into a prologue. It's a good way to set-up the game, story, and the controls and mechanics. It's a strong opener with some good set-pieces. The story follows as repercussions manifest and it's your job to stop the apocalypse. New AdditionsThere are a number of new features and experiences in this game that the previous ones lacked. First off, I highly recommend going into the settings and turning off the setting that paints all traversible ledges in white to mark your path for you. Turning this off really made it feel like I was making my own way through the wilderness, yet it did increase my play-time as I was hunting a little longer for those paths. It can also lead to you thinking you can grab onto some things in high-octane sequences that you can't, so get a token death sequence to wince at. -There are village hubs in this game, whereas the last 2 games opted for open 'playgrounds' with animals and resources to hunt for, this combines those with native population villages and so you can talk to the locals finding out about the area and small stories of the locals. Some even give you little side-missions to do. Trouble is these segments really slow down the pace of the game and story which is a real shame since the final act is VERY strong in my opinion. As is the opener, but the middle is a real let-down. That being said, it does make you feel like a tomb raider in the sense of establishing your archeological knowledge through local myth which is not out of place in the game. As said though, it does affect the pacing and possibly your motivation to keep playing the game.-There are other new things too like multiple weapons for an individual weapon i.e. different kings of shotgun, pistol etc which you can choose depending - I never bothered with them because it's just personal preference and I didn't care enough.There's also an interesting new skill tree with all sorts of small boosts to Lara, loads are locked off to you behind skill points, or dependent on completion of a challenge tomb... so I maybe had 50% of them by the time I finished the game. And again they never felt like they had a huge impact on the game when I got them. Apart from the longer breath underwater... but that's only because this game seems to ADORE throwing you into swimming sections for at least 30% of the game's story... -There is also this really quaint backstory section to build character where you play as Young Lara playing around her mansion in her own figurative mental playground, solving small puzzles which one only presumes her father constructed to as to enthuse his daughter into following him. It also helps with the payoff at the end of the game.-In short, all of the story sections have a place in the game.However there is, as with my thoughts on the previous games in the trilogy, a large number of things which do not have a place in the game. In my opinion.Sticks Out like a Sore ThumbThe playgrounds have always been a blessing and a curse for the new trilogy in my opinion. The first game got them right: they served as an exploration motivation: "Maybe I can find a tomb off in a corner somewhere". The only problem being that there weren't enough side-tombs in the first game. In the following games however these playground sections turned into "Resource Heaps" and "Collect-athons". Allow me to explain what I mean by this.CraftingIt's no secret that I really dislike the crafting systems in the new trilogy. I can just about abide the 'Salvage' from the first game, but in further games you have different coloured plants that give you bonuses to different things, different animal resources: feathers, pelts, venom, fur, leather. Along with the natural resources such as wood, mushrooms and the list goes on. What makes this worse is that resources are all too plentiful. I was full most if not all the time leading to me just waltzing through the playground sections because I had the resources, and I didn't have the gear to access the side-tombs usually blocked off at entry with some obvious hint like "You need the shotgun for this". At the early stage in the game you are once again forced to go through the "Tomb Raider surviving the wild" section... GROAN. So you have to find resources to kill aggressive animals to progress. In a word: it's a CHORE. And feels SO out of place in this and the previous game. Resources are used to craft ammo types, costumes and upgrades to weapons. Ammo types fair enough, but I just blasted my way through without using the other ammo types, because there was no need, the costumes are just a nice addition if you care about them, and upgrades to weapons... well that's just a staple of gaming.But they're too plentiful, my upgrades never felt like I was actually increasing in power, and the ammo types were superfluous to requirement. Indeed right at the end of the game it gives you a slew of new arrow types that you only get the opportunity to use in a single section - shame as they added some really fun and interesting quirks to the combat...Too much to collectAs with the crafting being forced and too plentiful, the collectables are also too plentiful along with the side-challenges. You have so many languages to learn to decipher monoliths to unlock clues to get a little bit of gold or maybe highlight a passage to a tomb... I just found myself asking myself: what's the point in doing these things for decidedly underwhelming rewards. The tombs are the only worthy challenge in my opinion. Too many languages and too many blocked areas and side-tasks and NO MOTIVATION TO BACKTRACK means that I finished the game with about a 70% game completion score with no motivation to get the other 30%! That is such a shame for a game boasting so many challenge tombs which I'm sure were all interesting in their own right, but I just never found myself caring about finding the needle in the haystack here. MAKE THESE CHALLENGE TOMBS PART OF THE MAIN GAME EXPERIENCE. Focused and centre-stage! CombatAs already alluded to, there are loads of great combat mechanics here. Really fun and satisfying... but they are only introduced right at the end and only viable for a small section of the game... come on! Less time collecting and hub-world-ing and more time having fun with these mechanics please! How To Improve?This game throws so many new good things at you, whether it's combat kill possibilities, traversal with rope-swinging etc, skill-trees, stealth, challenge tomb puzzles, lore enrichment in the villages, character and story development, locations, set-pieces, the overall feel and aesthetic of a tomb-raider game, and a great premise... But it falls short of being great because the game simply isn't consolidated. In a way it's like this review: overly bloated with words when I could have got my points across with bullet-points.The crafting needs to go... it's pointless and just adds busy-work.The combat opportunities need to be still more free-ranging and introduced earlier for maximum fun throughout the rest of the game, the collectables need a rethink. Different languages just bloats the game by an order of magnitude and adds to backtracking necessity without adding the motivation to do so... the rewards for side-tasks and riddles are underwhelming, and some traversals e.g. swimming are a little too forced and focused. Overall this is a good game with a great finale and characters, but I couldn't help thinking that with a bit more focus, and trimming the fat, this game could be very strong indeed!

Review of the ORIGINAL GAME with no DLC or expansions except the Aztec CivThe gist (unchanged from my Civ 5 review) as it still applies:Originally posted by Marshii:For those new to the game, the gist of it is this: You start off with just a city and a warrior unit from which you begin building at the 'dawn of time' and gradually expand your civilzation by gaining culture, advancing scientifically, building and using military, diplomacy, building new cities and buildings within those cities, and building enough 'improvements' to sustain an economy which can maintain the above. Because the map is tiled, each tile yields resources; perhaps a certain amount of food, construction, gold, or even another resource such as horses (needed to build horsemen etc) or iron, oil, even uranium (I don't need to tell you what that's for). As you progress you will find that you unlock more and more improvements, more buildings and more units that you can build, and if you play your diplomacy and development well enough, you will find that you can really start to get ahead of the competition; picture tanks versus musketmen - that can happen. Finally there are wonders which can provide a variety of benefits and a boost of culture. Benefits may include a free worker, reductions in costs for various things or even free technologies! Obviously getting a wonder before other people can therefore be of great importance. The main changes to Civ 6 include the following:Cultural 'Cards', or CIVICsInstead of the old government 'Social Policy' system where you choose a government with perks and travel down trees therein, effectively locking you into a longer, fixed strategy, the new Civics system is much more open to player choice and manipulation. Now, you still choose a government, but they now have different 'card configurations' in addition to subtle perks. You can unlock said cards and governements by advancing along the civics tree (Science Tree but for culture). Advancing along here will also get you buildings, units and abilities that you could not get in the Science Tree. This change makes for a much more replayable experience, however at the same time further takes away from the 'uniqueness' that each Civ 'should' display.Eureka Moments for Science and CivicsThese are tasks that you can complete to HALF the total time needed to research the item. For example killing a unit with a slinger will take Archery from a 6 turns to research down to 3. (Not sure if the numbers are correct off the top of my head). This adds an element of latent strategy into your game so that if you are focusing for a particular tech, you can gear yourself to all the Eurekas on that path to expedite your progress and get the edge on the enemy.Districts / Expanded CitiesEffectively, this means that not EVERYTHING is built on the single City tile. Chiefly this is a factor for DISTRICTS and WONDERS. Wonders now take up an entire tile per wonder and must be built within your borders. They each might have further pre-requisistes such as needing to be next to mountains or be on a desert and so on. They still give you perks on completion and disappear if someone beats you in constructing them.DISTRICTS are another main new feature of Civ6 which take up a tile outside of your city and contain the related buildings for that type of district. For example a Science district will add to your overall science and add further if a library, university, and so on, are constructed within. There are other types of DISTRICTS and they are all nicely colour coded which makes them really easy to read at a distance. There are Encampment (Military), Industrial (Production), Entertainment (Amenities/Happiness), Theatre (Culture), Religious, Economic, Harbour, Neighbourhood and Aquaduct(Housing/Population), Aerodrome (Aircraft) and finally a SPACEPORT (where the space race stuff is constructed).Districts also have adjacency bonuses so placement is important. Limited Worker ActionsWorkers can now only make 3 improvements before they 'expire ' and a new one must be constructed. This way you wont end up with a horde of workers by the end of the game.There are other changes as well such as Happiness is now Amenities, Religious Conquest is now a victory condition, 'Natural Wonders' now take up many squares, Barbarians are more intelligent and persistent (Be sure to kill their alerted scouts fast) and much more. City States also have quests that you can do for them to earn influence points which provide further beneifts if you have the most influence over them. Finally trade routes are now much easier too. In general, it's a much smoother experience in my mind than Civ5. Perhaps that's because I played the Board game version before 6 came out and many mechanics feel very similar, but Civilization 6 takes all the best bits of 5 and has them ready to go right at the start before any expansions are made. Civilization 6 is definitely not a buggy or unfinished mess. Is it worth the FULL asking price? Perhaps not, especially in the knowledge that expansions will inevitably be released and given that many more Civs will be purchaseable as DLC something I vehemently disagree with, especially at ¬£5-ish per civ. That is NOT worth the asking priceAI seems to have some improvements and indeed it will still give you a good game should you prefer not to play with others, but there are still issues. The major one is of course diplomacy. Each leader has a preferred style of government and different characteristics which will make them inherently dislike you if you so happen not to have the same religion or government as they do. This is infuriating and pointless as you bare witness to a neverending stream of spineless denouncings. Indeed, the only way that you are most likely to get in an alliance with an AI is by pandering to their every desire which removes the choice for the game entirely and you are effectively already playing second fiddle to someone else. It's a silly feature for the AI and needs to go.The art style in this iteration is pretty*hawhaw* polarising. Personally I think it works really well with the game and keeps me playing more than a more realistic style would, all the way down to the way the day and night now fade in and out as time progresses. In addition the soundtrack is great and Sean Bean narrating fits really well. Importantly, if you are new or returning to the series, the tutorial system has different settings depending on if you're familiar with the series or not which is great. The helpful built it 'wiki', the Civilopedia, makes a return here as well and is as helpful as ever if you are new. Though when I first used it when the game first released, it had some holes and omissions which I hope have been ammended. Finally, all that is left to mention is the replayability. This being a Civ game, there is an abundance of choice. Civs, Leaders, Maps, Victory conditions and more. There is so much customisation here as you'd expect and it really does help with keeping things fresh. That being said, it does still feel like Civs could still play more uniquely.  Civilization 6 is certinaly worth sale price, but if you are new to the series, perhaps try Civ5 complete. That is MUCH better in terms of price when on sale. Civ6 still has many DLC *ugh* to come out and some expansions down the line too. Ultimately, the choice is, as ever, yours. Civ6 gets my recommendation, but with the above caveats for NEW players.Be sure to check out my curator page

A fun game, as long as you are prepared to have patience with people with a lack of brain cellsThis game is free within the browser - Only buy on steam for the convenience of having it on the platform - You also get some free extras in game if you purchase on steam.In short, if you are familiar with the game Mafia, then you'll more or less get this game, except each player gets given a randomly assigned role at the beginning of play and each different role has abilities that can offer different elements of information. Most roles take place during the night and some have priorities over others. You can also write wills and death notes which are left behind in the unfortunate event of your death should you have any information that you can leave for the rest of your team. The rest of the game plays out in phases; Night where most player actions occur e.g. mafia can kill, jailor can imprison, doctor can heal someone, investigators can examine someone and a get a selection of possible roles, escorts can prevent someone's action from being taken and so on (there are a LOT of roles). Morning where dead players are revealed, the role that killed them, and their respective wills and death-notes are presented (and can be re-read later if needed). Day then follows with a Discussion phase wher players can talk, deliberate, accuse etc. Then the Vote where players can vote for someone to be lynched. There is a minimum number of votes required for someone to be called to the gallows. Should someone get enough votes, they have a few seconds to defend themselves without interruption, the other players then have a short time window to judge the player as either guilty or innocent, or abstain. The majority casts the decision of whether player lives or is hanged. (Keep in mind that judgements one way or another can also be considered information). If a player is a lynched, their role and will is revealed and the next night phase begins. Play continues with player numbers ever decreasing and possible roles being more and more limited until the town or other team win. I say other because there are many ways to play the game; classic gives the same roles which are known and only have town, mafia and serial killer - the mode for beginners and competitive ranked. There is also ALL ANY where anyone can be any role in the game, but if you play enough you start to see patterns in role assignment algorithms. Extra roles include Witches, Arsonists, Retributionists, Vampires, Vampire Hunters, Spies and so on. Vigilantics is witches and vigilanties (the latter choose someone to shoot at night, while the witches can control someone at night and force their action to be taken on the witch's preferred target - as you can imagine it gets crazy fast). There are also other modes and a new expansion, but they are not really worth the time, and I've played a fair bit of the game.As said above, the game requires patience as not all people have good reasoning or listening skills. The game itself is quite relaxing, unless of course you get right to the bitter end and tension mounts - there can be some great conclusions to games along with long strategies being played out. Such experience can be VERY rewarding. For example, I mostly play ALL ANY wherein there is a Werewolf role that can bite every other night. I went through the game not biting anyone so I wouldn't reveal who I was, and convinced the town I was a neutral role that I was not so they wouldn't visit me (at which point they may have been bitten, thus revealing my role). Right at the end of the game I convinced another neutral role to hang an evil role such that I won the game with them (as some roles win with others despite team allegiances).As you can tell from the above, the game takes a bit of time to learn because of the sheer volume of possible roles. Once you get a feel for the game, deduction and strategy, the game becomes a great, but calm test.

Review of the COMPLETE version - Including all major expansionsIt's good; get it. On sale, it's a steal; get it!With all the major expansions this is the essential Civilization game, and a great taster if you are thinking of Civ 6.For those new to the game, the gist of it is this: You start off with just a city and a warrior unit from which you begin building at the 'dawn of time' and gradually expand your civilzation by gaining culture, advancing scientifically, building and using military, diplomacy, building new cities and buildings within those cities, and building enough 'improvements' to sustain an economy which can maintain the above. Because the map is tiled, each tile yields resources; perhaps a certain amount of food, construction, gold, or even another resource such as horses (needed to build horsemen etc) or iron, oil, even uranium (I don't need to tell you what that's for). As you progress you will find that you unlock more and more improvements, more buildings and more units that you can build, and if you play your diplomacy and development well enough, you will find that you can really start to get ahead of the competition; picture tanks versus musketmen - that can happen. Finally there are wonders which can provide a variety of benefits and a boost of culture. Benefits may include a free worker, reductions in costs for various things or even free technologies! Obviously getting a wonder before other people can therefore be of great importance. Those are the basics and to new-comers that's more than enough to be getting on with and the AI can give you fairly decent games on a variety of difficulty settings. Equally, there are many, many, many map varieties for your prefered experience - you might want a map with no water, on the other hand maybe small scattered islands: You get a huge amount of customisation here, and it's not to be understated! On the subject of customisation; there are many, many different leaders you can play. The game even offers different leaders for a given civilization in some places; each leader provides differences to the civilization and so as you play with any given leader you want to keep their bonuses in mind and exploit them as best you can. It must be said though, personally I don't tend to notice a great difference between given leaders, the most noticeable thing is their unique units, but even those only last so long before technology supasses them. Maybe I'm just not pro enough. Yet, I play casually, and I enjoy it.The visuals are readable and clear which really helps for longer play times, and the soundtrack is different for each Civ and varies based on the era you are in or whether you are at war or peace. As the Brits, you may even recongise a good bit of Greensleaves in there too. For new players there is also a decent Civilopedia, essentially a wiki lookup for everything in the game, and even includes larger written backgrounds on each leader and Civ for the historically curious. Personally, I never really player online or with other people much so I can't really comment on that, but from the time I did spend with other people, I can say that it's an enjoyable experience, even when they march into your territory and refuse all of your offers of peace because, well, they know they are going to walk all over you... or me in this case; we've already established I'm not particularly good at this game. Another caveat though is that the AI can be a bit temperamental, though this has always been an issue with Civ games and remains one because they can never really act like a human (then again I haven't played at higher difficulties); they might denounce you for no reason, expand erratically, and so on. The final thing to say is that late game diplomacy can be a little... 'off'? Things like World Congress and United Nations - too me they became annoying po-ups every few turns that had little to no impact on the game other than that annoyance and were never really very well explained as to how some people end up with more diplomats than others, more voters and so on. But by that time I have a big enough nuclear arsenal that no matter how much the UN may not like it, I can kill everyone everywhere, like Mr Kim over there only dreams he could.In summary; it's a good game as a complete edition with all the expansions. On sale the bundle is more than worth it. Civ 5 Complete is a great entry into the 4X genre (4X = eXplore, eXpand, eXploit and eXterminate). Without the expansions though, Civ5 does have a few holes.

A refreshing, fun and adrenaline-pumping first-person shooter experience, marred by poor pacing, lack of story development and annoying auto-saves.I've played through the game twice now, and I can safely say that during my first play-through, I thoroughly enjoyed the game and really appreciate having a few proper FPS Boss sections rather than simply "Press E to beat Boss" nonsense that more mainstream FPSs spit out regularly. Yet, I did have to perservere through some very frustrating sections in order to get to those very enjoyable sections. I had been looking for an FPS that was not your standard COD/Battlefield fare where you just shoot and shoot and shoot with a bunch of set-pieces and an ever more outlandish story. Crysis doesn't follow down that path, though the story is somewhat sci-fi.Essentially you are part of an insertion team of super-soldiers whose super-suits grant you the use of 1 of 4 abilities at any one time which drain the energy of your suit when in use (energy recharges when not actively using an ability, as does health so long as you are not taking damage). These abilities are Armour (on by default this first drains your energy before your health is majorly impacted), Speed (Can move incredibly fast for repositioning, manouvres and rushing enemy positions), Strength (used to hurl objects much harder and further, punch through destructible cover, jumping higher and fall further without taking as much damage), Stealth (Enables a cloak that lowers energy all the while that it's in use, moving while cloaked lowers energy faster), you can also change the attachments to your weapons e.g. silencers, scopes and more. These abilities provide a refreshing gameplay experience as you become more proficient with using and switching between them as you really will start to feel like a super soldier tearing through waves of North Korean military who occupy the island. I only wish the energy bar lasted a little longer, but that might have had the outcome of being a little OP.To the gameplay, environment and story It's your pretty standard FPS, nothing too out of the ordinary here really. There are occasionally vehicles that you can drive, but these sections seem put in for the sole purpose of giving an impression of 'scale' to the island rather than actually being necessary in their own right. Afterall, the environments in Crysis are anything but linear corridors, you are usually given wide fields in which to fight, plan and execute your attack strategies on the unsupecting Koreans. Unfortunately, on a second play-through you realise just how similar these environments and 'play-grounds' are to each other, usually involving corrigated iron shacks for temporary cover or ammo dumps, lower metal fences for snap cover and the odd rock or tree. Certinaly on a second play-through this really adds to the gameplay feeling very stale indeed because of the next issue - the story pacing.The story is your generic action sci-fi with your super-suits, explosions, an archeological find going wrong and aliens suddenly giving the American Military a realisation that they are not the most powerful entity in the universe. Starting in a mode of rescuing the scientists from Korean clutches you explore and realise something more is afoot ultimately leading to the so called "Crysis", the namesake of the game. The problem is that a good 70% of the game is spent in those same environments as detailed above taking on Korean military time and again attacking outpost after outpost and you start to ask yourself - "Why am I still doing this and not doing something new and interesting?" This is precisely the problem with the game's pacing. This is amplified by the fact that the enemy types have to little to no variation within the Korean military and having to fight cloaked super Koreans comes a little too late and gets old and annoying fast. Equally, sometimes you get to fight a tank or get endlessly harassed by Helicopters. These can only be taken out by rocket launchers, and these only hold 3 rockets... despite 2 being required to take out a single chopper, and you can't stockpile rocket ammo meaning you'll constantly wasting a rocket after kiling a single chopper so you can pick up another full rocketlauncher in case you might need a good 2 rockets for future harassment. Yes, they do harass you, especially if you don't have rockets, these are a sure fire way to frustrate the player. - fortunately, by the time the aliens do actually get their time in the spotlight, the gameplay changes again as they require an almost entirely different approach, so what worked all game against humans; you might need to adapt and that really was a joy. I must admit that by the aliens show up you are approaching the climax of the game and on a first place you really will feel adrenaline as everything starts happening all at once and you are caught in the middle of devastation and a situation reminiscient of the Dunkirk evacuations as the US military suddenly turns into the French military and, well, runs away.One thing I did find most infurating however - autosaves. Because these are triggered by your location i.e. cross the pixel and you'll autosave - means that if you're one to go rambo and storm a position first with Super Speed, then you might find that your autosave occurs as you land encircled by Koreans and an attack helicopter. I cannot tell you how many times this happened to me and really ruined my enjoyment at times - the lesson is pace yourself and make sure you have been saving manually.All in all, there is a great game here, and by and large it shows itself, certainly on a first play-through as you gain proficiency with your new-found abilities. Though you will have to persevere through occasionally bullet-spongy enemies, annoying Helicopters, samey environments and objectives, and infuriating autosaves in order to get to the really good parts of this game which really do give the feeling of a crisis.

I saw the reviews and thought "It couldn't really be that bad could it? It's a genre that is more designed and catered for children, and grown-ups are reviewing it - of course it's not going to feel like the magic of your own childhood"Little did I know...First off, I backed this game on kickstarter and I must admit, the soundtrack and artbook are pretty lack-lustre so not even that was worth it. All the same, as a backer, and being a little late to actually playing the game because of life-things happening, I saw the reviews and tried to disregard them, but I've tried playing the game twice now, and while at first, yes the game does have an element of charm with it's nice pastel colours, bright environments and quirky characters; this is soon lost amongst bland, scattered, empty, lifeless worlds wherein enemies as so few and far between that you'll think you're playing some Bethesda RPG. I didn't get past the first world because of the frustration this game implanted in me. The camera is aweful where you'll have that classic jerky zoom problem where it can't figure out how to deal with little ledges. It also has issues of fixed camera angles at the dumbest of places e.g. jumping on a platform will automatically rotate the camera to be side on because it assumes you want to do the challenge associated with it, equally, there was another challenge that involved climbing a slide but at the bottom, you have to be close enough for the camera to face the slide, move one pixel away and it will then snap 180 degrees so the direction you were previously running in is now trying to take you in the opposite direction to where you intended... Dumb stuff like that. As I've said, enemies are generic, simple spin attack to win and there you go. Often they will just sit and stare at you waiting to be attacked... considering there are so few of them... maybe make them a challenge? The 'challenges' that I encountered in order to get my collectables to progress were also dull and unimaginative - race a cloud, turn into a flower and bob around super slowly to turn buds into plants, body slam some blocks, complete a time trial kart race-course with the worst controls that feel as though you have no grip at all, find ghosts that require 'catching' and other dumb things that aren't explained and are just left there for you to either perservere with or come back to later. Let me tell you this; In no way did this game make me want to come back later!The essence of the game is a collectathon so you'll be trying to get these 'pagies' and 'feathers' to progress both your worlds and your abilities. The latter is easy enough, the former are your main collectables. After you get a few, you can expand a world you have visited already. So, where previously I climbed and explored within levels only to find a random, inexplicable dead end where a path just stops, I now have a HUGE number of additional platforms and areas to explore, each at different corners of the world meaning I have more walking/rolling time through the level just to explore each of these new additions. Except these too aren't any extra fun and just add to the arbitrary nature of tasks the game has to offer with things like new bosses with silly slide climbing, indoor areas with more 'Come back when you have the power' locked doors and side-scrolling platforms. But get this - in a side-scrolling platform section, you still have 3d movement but a fixed camera so you can't see just a little gap at the deep end of a platform so you can slip down and have to start over... This is exactly what I mean when I say this game is just infuriating and poorly designed.Did I mention you have different abilities - I didn't play enough to really be able to experiment with them, but what I can say is built into the abilities is another fatal design decision - the stamina bar. You'd have thought that, with the size and scattered nature of the world design, that they'd at least let you move quickly right? Nope - rolling takes stamina from your incredibly small stamina bar meaning you'll need to recharge often. That is unless you roll through a butterfly which will refill your bar... except the butterflies are so hard to judge in terms of depth that colliding with them is a further frustration. Why did they add a stamina bar you may ask - so that they can have an arbitrary challenge of roll-racing a cloud around a track where you have to beat it on a single lap where you have to get these butterflies in order to prevent your stamina bar from depleting meaning you have to recharge, meaning you lose the race. It's that simple. It's just arbitrary, pointless and most importantly; It's. Not. Fun.In conclusion - I tried so hard to like this game, to give it a chance that I thought critics were not giving it. I kickstarted this game thinking "I haven't really played a classic 3D platformer like this before, let's see what I missed in my childhood". I come away disappointed in the soundtrack, the artbook, and most importantly; in the game, it has even put me off 3D platformers. I must admit defeat - while critics were able to sit through 'mine-kart' challenges and multiple worlds within this game, I gave in after only just expanding my first world; I haven't even come across these notorious mine-kart sections, and goodness knows I don't want to. I even heard there is a patch coming to sort out the voices etc, but trust me, that will be the least of your concerns.TL:DR - It's a half baked mess, a similar cooking-related, developer referencing pun would refer to this game as under-cooked Rare meat. I can't see how the nostalgia factor is ostensibly a saving grace for this game among fans of Banjo-Kazooie etc... It's just bland.Oh, and if you're thinking of buying this for your kids - don't. I can see many controllers, keyboards, mice and screens being broken in frustration.

Took me a few uninstalls till I could really get into the game, but now that I've made it about halfway through, I can truly say it's been worth all the heartache involved. If you ever wanted to feel like you're training for real to become a master shinobi, Sekiro will give you that feeling.

This game is a masterpiece. Beautiful, great atmosphere, and even an intriguing story hidden within small details. While these things are present in most of FromSoftware's games, Dark Souls 3 takes a new, but risky step in the series by adding a co-op feature. Now, I'm sure this angers many Dark Souls fans, as this feature seems like it would diminish the feeling of accomplishment gained from destroying a hard boss yourself. While this can be true if you rely too much on the co-op feature, I think the co-op option offers players the ability to continue progressing in the game, despite how alone or frustrated they may feel doing it alone, allowing many people to actually make it to the end of the game instead of uninstalling.

This game delivers part of it but not much especially for the price tag it has. Especially the multiplayer is bad. Not that the single player would be brilliantly better.

Great remake of original Half-Life. And improvements over Half-Life 2 and episodes too. Not missing flaws, but is expected to have for what started as a fan project.Half-Life 1 still stands on it's legs for it's time and is well worth playing as a trailblazing first person shooter. However Black Mesa is not just visual upgrade, but also updates(or rather reimagines) game levels, to be fresh and new to play, after having played through the original. Major improvements are to be found in boss battles.Better than Half Life 2 games in terms of visuals, but also gunplay. It reintroduces exotic weapons, that were present in original HL, but regrettably cut from following HL games.

I recommend it, if you have played and enjoyed previous XCOM games, but also want to experience something fresh. This is XCOM with a new spin on every mechanic. What remains true to the series, is still the never the less clunky user interface. Everything else is something new to adapt to. The single definite improvement that Chimera Squad have, it is that all playable characters are unique heroes with their own skill trees and abilities, rather than generic soldier classes. As for difficulty, it falls off a cliff at times. There is risk to run yourself into a corner. But then there is the final mission chain, that throws game balance out of window.

If you enjoyed XCOM Enemy Unknown, then I recommended XCOM 2 as continuation from that game forward. If you haven't played XCOM Enemy Unknown, then I think the best choice would be playing that game first, before XCOM 2. Thus I also review XCOM 2 based on how it compares to XCOM Enemy Unknown. What disappoints me is that XCOM 2 miraculously manages to get more clunky in it's interface than previous game. Still locks battlefield to only 4 restrictive viewing angles, rather than giving free ability to rotate it freely. Next, I dislike how Avenger controls are handled. Wrong button press, and I'm doing something I didn't want to, with no way to cancel it. And most annoying of all is the way I have to scan objects on map, that keeps getting interrupted by special missions. It made me quit playing game many times, until I forced myself to not take scanning seriously.In all other ways, I think this game shows either improvements, or comparable alternatives to what XCOM Enemy Unknown offers.

Great game. About the human test subject and robots. I wish though it did better at holding suspension of disbelief. Portal 1 was much better game in that regard, self sustaining believable world all the way through. Portal 2 often trades this magic away in favor of delivering more impactful story experiences.

It's up to you, to prevail on this challenge. What it means is that game won't to lead you by hand to victory, you have to craft the path yourself! If you do poorly, everything quickly snowballs out of your control. Results with soldier deaths, losing entire battles and losing entire game. That is why there is value here in doing your best! Aliens and ufos are waiting for you to come.

Gun looting-shooting adventure. Story, enemy variety, guns - taken to eleven! Character driven story, by one of most interesting villains from any video games that I have experienced.Biggest enemy variety from my experiences - no game I know stands even close.*Guns. Maybe Destiny 2 is something comparable?**Perhaps other Borderlands games does better, at guns and enemy variety departement. But BL2 excels at it's story! The BL2 story is long and with lows though, so be prepared for a lenghty adventure. - With tons of sidequests along the way!

What happens when you put an edgy teenager girl archetype as the main villain? - Borderlands 3. Loot. Looting. Looting and shooting - is the reason to play this game. As for story, you'll likely end up ignoring all of this annoying crap. Because main villain is someone to actively ignore, thus along with that it sets you in mood to ignore rest of the wacky story stuff as well.

Videogame that grips you with both story and gameplay, without letting it go. I'm not one to focus on story in games, so I won't comment on it. This is RPG mechanics done right. Normally, when presented with this many options, it takes finishing game once before in order to figure out the right way to build a character. In this game however I got ideas for picking skillpoints organically. Because I kept finding potentially interactive objects and items, that were locked under certain skill requirements, all the way to very last level of the game. I got lost during several parts however, due to unclear objectives. At one point during last stages of game I had to use magic powers of google in order to progress forward. I've been missing a mandatory movement technique - "mantling". "Mantling" as by pressing jump button you can climb up specific walls. If I didn't have internet powers, it would have been game over right there. Though it isn't like this game is designed to hold hands and I appreciate it. The core charm of this game is what makes it feel organic and immersive. - This game world. It is worth experiencing.

One of older games that seems to have aged terribly. Clunkiest gameplay from any game that I can remember. Where this game shines is in you piecing together story in your head. Learning and making sense out of information is necessary in order to figure out how to progress forward in this game.

One of games that lets player craft his own story in a procedurally generated world. My game play experiences are based on dying over and over again, thus finding more and more patterns and strategies relevant to survival. However essential parts of game are also hidden away from plain sight, thus I had to study resources outside of game.Downside is that this game is a time sink - you can't pause without exiting game and quitting game midway breaks game play flow. Thereby DST encourages long game play sessions without any breaks, lasting for many hours.

A classic game! You will be sure to wonder wtf is going on as you play through the game talking to weird and quirky characters. The aim is kind of clunky but it still works decently. Overall a good game for its price and you should definitely purchase this classic.

A dark game that requires endless amounts of skill, patience, time, and lots of trial and error. You'll be told "git gud" a lot and will die countless times. I came to this game for my love of chickens. When playing the game, I realised that not every map had chickens on it, so I slowly got angrier with the game....The lack of chickens boiled my blood. I think I was one of the few people who bought this game with no expectations whatsoever. I wasn't even planning to buy it before the release, but I decided to give it a try and was extremely disappointed.The combat is the main aspect that brings this game down. For it to be such a significant part of the game and still be so unimaginably poorly designed is genuinely shocking. I could understand if they tried to go for a new twist on combat that just didn't work out, but that's clearly not the case: the combat is extremely generic and basic, and they still somehow managed to make their rudimentary system feel clunky and horrible to play.The level to which your decisions influence the course of the game is also much more limited than it seems to be at first glance. I was actually impressed in the beginning at how much seemingly small decisions affected the story, only to realize upon watching other playthroughs that they had no effect whatsoever.Overall, if you're interested in a (slightly) interactive story, this game may be interesting to try out. However, the combat is so atrocious that there is no way I can recommend this game without an extreme rework.

This game is NOT worth 60 dollars, but the greedy Ubiosoft will never lower it to a reasonable price, so it's best to wait for a sale. DO NOT buy the discounted starter edition, as to unlock any new heroes it requires 8-15 hours to get enough currency to buy them, and those cursed hours will cause you to feel the worst pain of your life as the horrible gameplay lights the flames of anger within your mind and sends your blood pressure further out of this solar system than Voyager 1.In the ironically named "For Honor", the only gamemode that consistently has high activity is Dominion 4v4. However, there will be no situation in horrible bonfire of broken dreams where you will actually have an exchange which involves a nanogram of skill. You will be attacked by three or more enemies and have no chance of letting your starved blade take a chunk out of their pitiful excuses for bodies. Or, you and your team will all attack one sad, hopeless enemy and all you have to do is spam buttons until their crumpled form lies at your feet, no lesser in skill in death than they were in life. In the rare occasion that you have the opportunity to fight in single combat, another of the honorless swine will sneak up behind you and bring down a ferocious strike of mercy down on your skull, liberating you from the cruel chains of playing a single match of this disgusting piece of flotsam that is somehow marketed as "fun".

I have played only 3 games and I could not bear to play another.I might be writing this review as positive except I immediately got kicked out of 3 different games that I tried to join before they even started. Maybe I would have had more positive experiences in those, but I guess I'll never know.There is NO teamwork in the game. Half of the time is spent with people either not doing anything, or killing civilians, or waiting for other people to do things that never get done until we're almost out of time.The "Point of No Return" mechanic simply takes away from the game. At least let us fight the cops and at least have a chance of winning after the point of no return, not  just fail us immediately, especially with all the wasted time.I see now why this game is being given away for free, but I believe I still overpayed. The roblox version is honestly higher quality.

This game very fun to play. Most of all the aspect of discovery, such as finding chests and getting the contents, or learning about the vast amount of weapons and loot you can get.However, this game is no longer fun for me.The game is incompatible with Steam cloud saves, so using the steam cloud basically just deletes your local saves. Since I play on multiple computers, when I logged back on to one of them, Steam asked me if I wanted to use cloud or local saves. Since in the game I have it saved to cloud so I can use multiple computers, I assumed it would be the same on Steam.However, doing this wiped basically 50% of the world's progress, so now I feel no reason to play if all of my progress will just be taken away.Would not recommend.

While this game is surely interesting, the combat is what brings it down. First of all, sidestepping or dodging out of attacks in not possible at all. The enemies stay at the same position in front of you constantly no matter how much you move, meaning that you will have to block every attack. This would not be as much of a problem if the block negated all of the damage, like it does in most games. However, in this case, parrying saves you from some of the damage, but not all of it. Even if you block every attack perfectly, you will still die if you are fighting against an opponent with a large health pool or if you were at low health when the enemy attacked you.Overall, this game has an interesting concept of a pirate-themed procedurally generated world, but it is brought down by its poor combat mechanics and some other features which I will not go into depth for.I look forward to seeing how this game progresses, but for now, I would not recommend it.

I would not recommend this game at all. They immediately throw you into fights with enemies that can easily lock on to you constantly and never miss, while you're still trying to figure out the terribly designed controls. It's barely possible to stop yourself from constantly flying around since you have to accelerate the perfect amount and then stop to stop drifting, making it even more difficult to fight since you can only turn at a slow rate and can't come about to face all the fighters coming at you from many different angles. You can't even bind mouse buttons to keys to make things easier.3/10

I don't like anything about this game. The combat is terrible, and it is basically impossible to block because even when I move my mouse in the right direction it doesn't do anything.There is nothing to stop people from just running away, when I'm about to kill someone they just run back to their team and heal up a bit, then come back and double team me so I can't do anything.The name is false advertising. There is no honorable combat in this game at all, it is rare that the fights are actually even.And the idiotic idea to kick players out of the middle of a match for "low fps". My FPS was perfectly fine, over 30, but I got kicked out of a match I was about to win because Ubisoft made a dumb call by making this terrible feature.If you preordered this, cancel it if you can.

Much better than Medieval Warfare. In DW the combat is a bit simpler and a lot more fun, with a lot less ridiculous spinning, dragging, and feinting. Also there are more diverse classes to choose from, so almost any playstyle can be used. Community is also friendlier than MW. If you own MW, I would definitey suggest trying out this game.

This game definitely has the possibility of being fun. However, it wasn't as fun for me as I think it could have been. My favorite part was using a variety of weapons, like shotguns, assault rifles, and katanas. Except I think this game is a bit too difficult. Especially since attackers can just appear randomly from anywhere.Also, there are sometimes messages that come up and break up the game. These were normal for a while, but after a few levels they started to get a bit creepy, which I didn't like.I might come back to this game later, but for now I'm going to put it away for a while and maybe come back to play it some other time. However, if you like a very challenging game, I would definitely suggest this. If you want a game that is a bit less challenging, I would suggest something else.

Reign of Kings is definitely a game with a lot of potential, but it is not very well made, and has a lot of issues.First of all, I'll talk about the good things about the game. It's very easy to understand how to do the various necessary things in this game like gathering, crafting, and fighting, among others, with simple controls that make it much less difficult to become accustomed to than some other games. The map is small enough that you will run into other players occassionally, but not so large that you feel isolated and have to actively go hunting for other players to find any. Overall, this is definitely a solid game, other than the few bad things that I'll talk about now.Glitchy animations are definitely a problem. There are a few harmless ones, but there are others that make the game overly difficult and unfair. This appears primarily in fighting. Sometimes an animation can fail to play correctly and result in you being hit without even knowing that they were attacking.Another thing that I've found wrong with the game (this may not be a "problem" because I see why it was added to the game, but it's just something I don't like personally) is the amount of health on building blocks. If the block is claimed, it can take hundreds of strikes on it to destroy it, depending on the material and your weapon. This makes attacking bases almost impossible without siege equipment, even when attacking building make out of leaves and sticks.I do not recommend buying it unless the price is lowered, 20 dollars is too much for a fairly broken game.

Was looking for something like the board game 'Traffic Jam', and this is the closest I've found. Fun to just mess around with - also you can beat some of the levels' 'best known' move sets

I decided to run through single player part of the game for the (3rd?) time, it's been a fair amount of years since I've done so. The game doesn't hold a light to games these days, it blows holes of fire through them. Every bit of dialogue slaps, every joke hits, and the puzzles are well designed. If you don't have this game by now, don't even wait for a sale, just buy it; an absolute masterpiece
Very cute, relaxing, rogue-lite, platformer. Beautiful little look and soundtrack, great way to chill

Absolutely gorgeous game. The colors, the soundtrack, the simplicity in movement. Incredible game, was an absolute pleasure to play. Took a bunch of screenshots as I went through and have a lot of new backgrounds to enjoy

I can't think of a game that I feel my money was better spent. I got the game for $10 (it frequently goes on sale for that) but after playing, it's worth more than even the full price. It has such creative and varying environments. The game is absolutely gorgeous, as it is a completely hand drawn game. There are a bunch of unique and interesting areas, enemies, and bosses; this game has so much packed in to such a low price.A truly incredible experience if you enjoy metroidvanias, one of the best in its category. The only other game I've enjoyed as much at this price range is Hyper Light Drifter, another incredible game.

I got this game in the Summer Steam Sale and actually feel bad about paying half price. The developers deserver 100% of the potential revenue this game could generate. Everything is gorgeous, the soundtrack, the environments, the fight sequences. This game is a perfect balance of skill and fun; you can't just run over enemies mindlessly, but you aren't going to die 50 times in a specific area (the bosses are understandably harder, so you will die several times for each of those). For some reason, I felt like this game told an amazing story with very little background or dialogue at all. I don't know how, but every action is satisfying, even though there isn't much noticeable progression at all. There are really no explanations of why you're doing what you're doing, but you still do it and feel accomplished. It's hard to explain how a game can be so captivating but have very little story told; that's a reason why I think it's so phenomenal. As for the actual gameplay: movement is the most satisfying of the game. You can progress well even if you aren't skilled. But once you start understanding the mechanics and the best ways to move and slash, you feel amazing after completing any sort of challenge. I know a lot of games where boss battles are either a grind or a joke, and not very satisfying in the end. The bosses in HLD are difficult, but I've been satisfied with myself after completing each of them because the fights really make you feel like you've learned your mechanics well. This game has jumped to my favorite game of all time; if you hadn't gotten that from the review already. I haven't played games so fluid on a controller, so this was an amazing gameplay and visual experienceLong after completing the game, going back to find all of the collectables is very enjoyable because you get to re-experience some of the game

I 100% recommend that you play this game, especially if you like the ocean and fish, just wait for any sort of sale and buy it, no questions asked. I loved this game, it is absolutely gorgeous. You basically just swim around with fish in a beautifully rich environment. I say to wait for a sale because the story is minimal, and the gameplay is linear; you basically go from one place to another, and there are no challenges. I can't stress enough how pretty the game is, but there isn't really enough story to warrant the $20 price. That being said, there is a ton of content in the form of fish inclusion and variety. Also, the soundtrack matches perfectly with the gameplay, there are places that you can sit and admire the entire area or each fish individually, which is incredibly neat because the devs seem to have put in a lot of time to include as many fish as you could ever want to look at.Really a unique gameplay experience that I've never had before

Definitely a game worth the 98 cents on sale. You get about 30 minutes of gameplay to 100% the game. It's super chill and relaxing, definitely worth the time, and has a cute little ending. I'd say it's worth your time if you're looking to lay back and enjoy some fun jumping mechanics and tranquil music.

Overall one of my favorite games that I've playedI can't really think of other games that it is like, perhaps 'A Story About My Uncle' in the 3D platforming sort of sense.I've enjoyed this game so much because I love freedom of movement in games, and this game really allows you to go and do what you want. The enemies are basically a joke. I play on a macbook that dips a lot in frames during any sort of fight scence, but you will really never get killed by an enemy. Also, you are rewarded for jumping around and collecting more acorns because you can open monument walls and get upgrades to your suit that make following sequences easier. I generally explore games because I like seeing everything, so I really enjoy the reward system in place for doing so. The story is fun enough; I like the audio tapes idea because you get to see how people in the area that you're discovering were thinking. I've been suggesting this game to everyone I know, I picked it up on a 50% sale, and still worth it, anything like that or lower, I would say that this should be a definite buy

The game has a portal-environment feel. There is no puzzle-solving of sorts, you just walk around and take different paths to get different story. Entertaining for a very short amount of time. There are so many permutations of routes that you can take, that actually seeing all of them would take a very long, painstaking amount of effort

READ ME FIRST: This problem has been sort of fixed, there are save locations now throughout the levels and it does fix most of my problems. I still believe that it‚Äôs annoying with this system, but I won‚Äôt complain too much about it since I‚Äôm very happy that they did put some form of checkpoints throughout. The main problem has been fixed, the rest may just be something wrong with how I play it, but I think you should still think about this before you buy it. It may not be a problem for you. But other than annoying inconveniences, the game has been improved a lot and is easily more playable now.So, thanks for that Stress level zero.The review:This game is great. Now that‚Äôs out of the way and I can now say why I didn't recommend this game, and why I don't want to play it anymore.The game is so good when you play through it and have a lot of time to play it in one go, but I don‚Äôt have that. The checkpoints keep resetting me really far back, and therefore my progress has been set back many times and it's so bad for me that it makes me mad each time I open the game. I'm unmotivated to play it because each time I leave and I think that the game knows how far I‚Äôve went, it just resets me so all my progress, that I've used like half an hour on, is gone. And this is so annoying that I don't know if I really want to play it any more.EDIT: While this problem still Occurs, it is much smaller time periods that you get set back. And while i still dont really want to play it anymore is probably because i have other games that i can easily start up and shut down again, without losing pogress.And yes, you can argue that I can wait to I have more time on my hands or that I'm just slow at the game, but that doesn‚Äôt change that the game doesn‚Äôt remember anything between the checkpoints, and that‚Äôs really annoying when I have to do the same thing‚Äôs all over again because I didn‚Äôt go thru the hole area, and I haven‚Äôt really figured out when there specifically is a check point.EDIT: The checkpoints are easily visible now, and there is some throughout a level. Note that I have changed my stand on the game because I actually have enough time on my hands to play the whole thing through, and with the help of the new checkpoints. And I do believe it is a great game. This was not written out of rage since I was so annoyed by this saving system they had, most of my problems have thankfully been solved.The game can still be perfect for you.Thanks again Stress level zero for fixing this.I will  recommend this game now, because the main issue that drove me away got fixed, it just didn‚Äôt seem to pull me back in. It is a great game, the experience has just been ruined for me.

The game is very funny and a nice refresher to the original. There is points of this that I can say that the price might not be completely worth it but read along and you might find out if this might be for you or not.First I wanna say as someone who never played the original but saw Youtube videos about this was very nice to see and experience. The original endings are there with some twists here and there and once the little companion that's unlockable gets unlocked new things pop up. For spoiler free reasons I won't mention what it is but I will say that dialog changes whether you choose to have it with you or not. Now I mentioned that the game wouldn't be completely worth the price it is at and the reason for that is... the old endings are still very much there and still quite a big part in most of the game. The new content that was made for the game was honestly mind blowing and a super fun experience (blew 3.5h away when I first booted the game). I will still say that the old endings sure did bring some smiles back to the face and some very nice memories happened during play time. I do wish there could be a bit more for the price it is at and therefor is another reason I cannot recommend the game at the current price. although the price is high the game is still very much enjoyable, makes someone like myself laugh (I can be quite hard to make laugh) and spend bunch of time on the game without even realizing how long that i've been playing. If you never played the original give this one a shot. If you did play the original playing this would still be amazing though if you can get it for a bit cheaper price than what it is at I would definitely do that.

The game is absolutely great and I got addicted quick. Once you get the hang of the game you just feel the need to go faster and faster and look much cleaner. If you have played SEUM and felt the need to speedrun there this game will hit you just as hard or even harder as it did for me. The game is gorgeous, feels great and runs pretty damn smoothly. For a newly released game I would give it a solid 8.5/10. The only problem that I find a little annoying the how ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• GOOD THE NPCS ARE AT HITTING YOU. Thought its a minor detail and doesn't matter much. There is quite a bit of different enemies so there is a good learning curve there already not to mention the amount of skips, speed tactics and techniques that you have at your disposal. I seriously recommend trying the game out and play it all the way through. The game can be frustrating on some points but it is a game made for speed and there is more to the game than meets the eye. I highly recommend trying it out.

A hilariously fun game. The combat system is very unique and very easy to grasp. The style of the fighting is more of a Rock, paper scissors kinda thing with more strategy and a lot of button mashing with it. Playing the Arcade mode is super fun and the supported custom characters are a great twist. Having played it with but the free and full version I can say there isn't too much change in the game. Of course you cannot play all characters with the free version but you are allowed to play custom characters that people have made. Quick warning as the special and super the customs has are already from in game characters. The animation that people make for them and how they look are custom in itself. For the style of the game it is super fun and great to play in. The way the game was made makes it feel like raging isnt a thing as its more like "If you mash the fastest you win" kinda thing where most of the time either you dominate or get absolutely dominated. I highly recommend BOTH versions of the game. Either one is fine as they are both really close to each other. The money for the full version is worth it as all characters has a cosplay for them and there is 2 additional characters that you can unlock by playing. The leveling system is super easy to level up in and doesn't take much time at all. You can just play against friends or the CPU if that is what you desire and you will still gain quite a bit of EXP out of it. Hilarious game. Super fun to play and highly recommended.

If you read this and questions whether the game is good or not keep reading and I will tell you most of what you need to know jumping into a conclusion.First of I have to say this game absolutely blew my mind and told one of the best stories that I have EVER played and experienced. Is the game worth the money? Oh hell ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô?yes it is. So to begin with as you may notice you are a fox in the game. Without spoiling anything I won't tell anything that goes gameplay wise.As said you are a fox that travels. You then go through some challenges to complete whatever it is you have to do. The story it self is very unique and doesn't actually tell you what it's truly about but when you go through the game it doesn't feel like you just walk through a world that has a laid out path for you. The exploring for the game can take so much time and everything just looks so beautiful that you could just keep exploring the paths that is there. Some places are easy to navigate and some aren't. Just a heads up for anyone going into this game the devs have made paths that are easier to solve than what it seems.For my own personal experience of how I played and how long it took I was immersed the entire way through and didn't actually feel like 3.5hrs of playtime. The game is very uniquely made and is absolutely fantastic with great music playing in the back to keep you highly entertained the entire way. The puzzles in the game also makes it feel very fresh and the ending was the biggest mind blowing ending that I have experienced. The way the game ends truly makes the entire time super satisfying and worth while. I highly and I do mean HIGHLY recommend trying the game out as it is super great and has a seriously good story which I cannot say enough. The graphics are fabulous, the story is amazing and the music is great with a good twist of world making, exploration and puzzles that feels fresh.Highly recommended.

Sea of Thieves is a really fun game and is quite enjoyable. I do recommend playing it with friends as it not only gets easier to manage everything but also becomes a lot more fun. In Sea of Thieves you cannot play offline and grind for fun you automatically play online on servers with other players. With my experience and how I encountered the game the more players you have the more players there will be on the server (that was my experience and how my friends and I encountered it). Playing alone puts you on a tiny ship where another player can be. When you are on a 3 man the boat gets bigger and harder to manage I do not know whether it changes again with 4 people I played in a 3 man group. The 2 man boat is the easiest to not just control but also to manage but it isn't as fast as the 3 man ship.It has a fairly nice grinding mechanic to it. You find an island, plunder the stuff that is there (if you don't have a mission) and leave. If you have missions you find the island you are suppose to go to and do either solve the riddle or dig up the treasure from the treasure map that you will receive.The game do have events which are showed in the sky (you'll know what I mean when you see it) which all players can see and go to.The game can have people that try and just kill you and your boat which is a bit annoying but it is to be expected when the game is literally just "plunder all you can". If you go into the game and play it when you see another ship you can expect it to either see you and go for you or not see you and just go away. There is some players that will ally up for some time so they can complete what they have and then just sail off.Overall the game is really fun and puts you somewhat into the shoes of a pirate and how it technically could be. Super fun game really beautiful to look at as well and is definitely recommended to play but mostly only with friends as it becomes even more fun. More so when you bully them a bit :)

The games mechanics are really unique and are actually quite fun. I haven't played the multiplayer aspect of the game yet but I messed around with the characters in training (which they have for you to train in for combos and such) which are an arena with edges that you can fling the bot off of. The tutorial for the game teaches you the very basics of the game that you need to know. It doesn't hold your hand very far but gets you through most of the stuff that you need to know. HOWEVER, the tutorial made me stuck once and I had to quit the game and restart the tutorial but it isn't a very long tutorial so it doesn't matter too much.The graphics for the game are actually really good and really sets the mood for the game. It has a very unique way of telling its story and thats just in the training arena and the tutorial that I saw. For the multiplayer world I don't know how it looks but I can imagine it being just as pretty.The mechanics for the game are a bit weird at first but they aren't so bad as you would think. They are quite good and will most likely get much better in the future. For the price I couldn't really say whether it's worth the money or not I guess that comes down to if you really like an arena fighting game that puts in the style of closer to Battlerite and Smite combined in a way with a few tweaks. I got the game for free on a bundle so for me the game is actually really worth it. I guess it's one of those "try and see if it's for you" kinda game. Personally I recommend it.

First of all I only recommend this game if you are into the sort of games that supports an all around fighting challenge. In this game you will encounter a lot of range abusers and other things that people will do to win. Certain characters helps in certain ways and I can only say play the style you feel like is best. If you are the one who goes range and uses mainly that you will get hated on as the style is frowned upon quite a bit. The game has a very unique way of being played and takes a lot of battle experience to get really good in. The combo system is also really hard to understand but has a decent way of showing who is skilled at their combos and who isn't. For the story I would say that it's weird and for the most part doesn't make much sense to me. To put it simply without spoiling anything for anyone who wanna try it for themselves it's sorta like Xenoverse 2's story. The game has a lot of different characters and has a lot of different moves that you can use for your own CaC which I love about the game and is by far the best about the game if you ask me. If you wanna make a character who are a brawler there is a ton of moves that supports that style and even makes it feel like you made a character for an anime. What sets the CaC's in this game apart from any other CaC supportive game that I have played is the fact that YOU get to choose what fighting style your character goes with. You wanna fight sorta like a martial artist? Well the game lets you. The game even has a brawler and a pirate style that you can fight as. You can even use a sword style that they put in. Whether it has more or not I don't know. For me Jump Force is a game I can come back to and mess around in but is not the game I would play on a regular basis. The game has it's flaws and as any other game isn't perfect. Though the graphics and how the game is played makes it feel like you play an actual anime and with the flaws that the game has weirdly enough puts you into that perspective quite a bit more. I personally don't regret buying the game as I can always come back to it and mess around for a bit more.My final conclusion is that you should watch videos about the game and really ask yourself whether it is the sort of game you would be able to play once in a while or if it'll just lay there in your library.

The game is fun and has changed a lot through out the course.In my personal opinion the game can be very enjoyable considering both co-op and single player. They changed a lot from preview game since towers in this one has a 5th tier upgrade and an extra upgrade path for all monkeys. The monkey knowledge there is in the game is really unique and changes a lot in the style of how the game is played. Not only that but you can also buy heroes with in-game currency that you get from completing maps and difficulties. Freeplay is achieved after you complete your little "quest" which is super easy to do. Maps are changed into different difficulties and can be easily unlocked by completing other maps. Bloons TD 6 also has events thats like challenges that other players has made that you can play. By completing these you can get in-game currency and sometimes there is even a race up for you to try and complete the course as fast as possible. I really recommend the game to people that personally likes grinding and likes strategy as the game is heavily based on how well you manage your towers, upgrades and income to survive the horde of bloons that is coming your way.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pieDirections:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.
